reg:regulation.reg:acttitle: Court Rules Act and Small Claims Act
reg:regulation.reg:title: Small Claims Rules

bcl:section.bcl:text: The purpose of these rules is to make it as easy as possible for people to use the court to resolve their disputes. If necessary, there will be a trial and a judge or a justice will decide the claim. However, both sides are encouraged to try to come to an agreement. A settlement is always possible, even after a judge or a justice has made a decision.

bcl:definition.bcl:text: business day means a Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday that is not a holiday;
civil resolution tribunal means the Civil Resolution Tribunal established under the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act;
claimant means the person who is making the claim;
court means the Provincial Court of British Columbia;
creditor means a person to whom, by order of the court, a debtor must pay money;
debtor means a person who, by order of the court, must pay money to a creditor;
defendant means the person against whom the claim is made;
hearing includes a trial;
justice means a judicial justice or a justice of the peace;
method of attendance, in relation to a conference, hearing or mediation session, includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: attending in person, and
attending by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: tribunal accident claim means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an accident claim, as defined in the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act, and
a claim purported to be an accident claim, as defined in the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: tribunal small claim means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a tribunal small claim, as defined in the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act, and
a claim purported to be a tribunal small claim, as defined in the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act;

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Completing a notice of claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To make a claim, other than a claim to which Rule 1.1 applies, a person must complete a notice of claim (Form 1) and an address for service (Form 38), following the instructions on the forms.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing a notice of claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claimant must file a notice of claim and an address for service and pay the required fee at the Small Claims Registry nearest to where

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant lives or carries on business, or
the transaction or event that resulted in the claim took place.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the defendant is a company
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant is a company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act, the claimant must file with the notice of claim a printout of a search showing the most recent address of the registered office of the company on file with the Registrar of Companies.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the defendant is a society
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant is a society within the meaning of the Societies Act, the claimant must file with the notice of claim a printout of a search showing the delivery address and mailing address of the society's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claimant wants to claim against more than one defendant
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claimant may name more than one defendant in a notice of claim, but only if the claim against each defendant is related to or connected with the original subject matter of the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the claim is for more than $35 000
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claimant who has a claim amounting to more than $35 000, not including interest and expenses, may abandon part of the claim so that the balance of the claim may be heard in the court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Litigation guardian needs Public Guardian and Trustee's consent
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person (litigation guardian) who makes a claim for personal injury on behalf of someone who is under 19 years of age or under another legal disability may abandon part of the claim under subrule (4), but only with the consent of the Public Guardian and Trustee.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Abandoning part of a claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To abandon part of a claim, a claimant must say on the notice of claim that the amount over $35 000 is abandoned.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of abandoning part of a claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (7), a claimant who abandons part of a claim may not at any time sue for that part, unless the whole of the claim is withdrawn under Rule 4 (9) and then pursued in the Supreme Court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of transfer on abandonment
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claim is transferred to the Supreme Court under Rule 7.1, the claimant may sue for the whole amount to which the claimant may be entitled whether or not part of the claim was abandoned in the Provincial Court.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Process for Making a Claim if Proceedings Previously Initiated before Civil Resolution Tribunal

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: filing party means the person who completes and files a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim (Form 34);
initiating notice has the same meaning as in the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act;
initiating party has the same meaning as in the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act;
response means a response made under section 7 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claim to which this rule applies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule applies to a claim if one or more of the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the civil resolution tribunal has made a final decision in relation to the claim, and a party has filed a notice of objection under section 56.1 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act;
after the civil resolution tribunal has given the initiating party an initiating notice in relation to the claim, the civil resolution tribunal has refused to resolve the claim;
the court orders that the civil resolution tribunal not adjudicate the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Completing a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To make a claim in respect of which this rule applies, a person must complete a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim (Form 34) and an address for service (Form 38), following the instructions on the forms.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Identification of parties for notice of civil resolution tribunal claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a claimant is the initiating party who made the initial request to the civil resolution tribunal and who was first given an initiating notice in relation to a claim in the proceeding before the civil resolution tribunal,
a defendant is, in relation to the initiating notice referred to in paragraph (a), a person who was required to make a response, and
a third party is a person, other than a claimant or defendant, who was required to make a response in the proceeding before the civil resolution tribunal referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person must file a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim at the Small Claims Registry nearest to where

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant lives or carries on business, or
the transaction or event that resulted in the claim took place.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the defendant or third party is a company
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant or third party is a company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act, the filing party must file with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim a printout of a search showing the most recent address of the registered office of the company on file with the Registrar of Companies.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the defendant or third party is a society
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant or third party is a society within the meaning of the Societies Act, the filing party must file with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim a printout of a search showing the delivery address and mailing address of the society's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Documents to be filed with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The filing party must file the following with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the following documents in respect of all tribunal small claims that were to be resolved in a single proceeding before the civil resolution tribunal:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: all initiating notices received by the filing party;
all responses received or made by the filing party;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one of the following documents in respect of a tribunal small claim referred to in paragraph (a):

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a certificate provided by the civil resolution tribunal to the filing party under section 56.2 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act;
a notice provided by the civil resolution tribunal to the filing party to notify the filing party that the civil resolution tribunal refuses to resolve the tribunal small claim;
a copy of the order, made under section 16.2 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act, that the civil resolution tribunal not adjudicate the tribunal small claim;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an address for service (Form 38).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claim continued
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claim made by a claimant against a defendant and set out in an initiating notice filed under subrule (8) with a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim is continued as a claim made under these rules against the defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claimant who is not the filing party must file an address for service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claim is continued under subrule (9) and the claimant is not the filing party, the claimant must file an address for service (Form 38) and serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Serving a Notice of Civil Resolution Tribunal Claim

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What must be served on the other parties?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The filing party must serve each of the other parties named in the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the other party's copy of the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim;
a copy of the documents filed under subrule (8) with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim;
a blank reply form (Form 2) for each claim made against the other party for which the other party does not have a response continued as a reply under this rule;
a blank address for service form (Form 38).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve an individual
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If any of the other parties referred to in subrule (10) is an individual, the documents referred to in subrule (10) (a) to (c) must be served on the individual by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: leaving a copy of those documents with the individual, or
mailing a copy of those documents by registered mail to the individual.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve a company
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If any of the other parties referred to in subrule (10) is a company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act, the documents referred to in subrule (10) (a) to (c) must be served,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the company has a registered office,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by delivering a copy of those documents to the delivery address shown for that registered office in the office of the Registrar of Companies, or
by mailing a copy of those documents by registered mail to the mailing address shown for that registered office in the office of the Registrar of Companies,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the company's registered office has been eliminated, in the manner ordered by the court, or
in either case, by leaving a copy of those documents

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at the place of business of the company, with a receptionist or a person who appears to manage or control the company's business there, or
with a director, officer, liquidator, trustee in bankruptcy or receiver manager of the company.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve an extraprovincial company
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If any of the other parties referred to in subrule (10) is an extraprovincial company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act, the documents referred to in subrule (10) (a) to (c) must be served

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by delivering a copy of those documents to the delivery address shown for the head office of the extraprovincial company in the office of the Registrar of Companies if that head office is in British Columbia,

by mailing a copy of those documents by registered mail to the mailing address shown for the head office of the extraprovincial company in the office of the Registrar of Companies if that head office is in British Columbia,

by mailing a copy of those documents by registered mail to the mailing address shown in the office of the Registrar of Companies for any attorney appointed for the extraprovincial company under Division 2 of Part 11 of the Business Corporations Act,
by leaving a copy of those documents with the attorney, or
if no attorney has been appointed, by following subrule (12) (c).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve a partnership
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If any of the other parties referred to in subrule (10) is a partnership, the documents referred to in subrule (10) (a) to (c) must be served by mailing a copy of those documents by registered mail to a partner, or by leaving a copy of those documents

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with a partner,
at a place of business of the partnership, with a person who appears to manage or control the partnership business there, or
with a receptionist who works at a place of business of the partnership.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Other service rules — see Rule 18
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (16), the provisions in Rule 18 apply if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any other party referred to in subrule (10) of this rule is a municipality, a person under 19, a society, an extraprovincial non-share corporation within the meaning of the Societies Act, or an unincorporated association including a trade union,
the filing party needs to serve the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim on a person outside British Columbia, or
the filing party is having difficulty serving any other party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application of Rule 18 in relation to third parties
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of applying Rule 18 to a claim to which this rule applies,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reference in Rule 18 to a "notice of claim" must be read as a reference to a "notice of civil resolution tribunal claim",
a reference in Rule 18 (8) to a "claimant" must be read as a reference to a "filing party", and
a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim may be served on a claimant or third party in the same way as required for service of a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim on a defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit for service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim has not been served within 28 days after it was filed it expires, but the filing party may apply to have it renewed (see Rule 16 (3)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party has not filed an address for service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Until a party files an address for service (Form 38), documents must be served on the party at the address for service, if any, that the party provided to the civil resolution tribunal.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Replying to a Claim Continued under this Rule

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Previous response continued as a reply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A response made by a defendant is continued as a reply to a claim if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant made a response in respect of the claim when the claim was proceeding before the civil resolution tribunal as a tribunal small claim,
the response is filed under subrule (8) with a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, and
the claim is continued under subrule (9).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Defendant who is not the filing party must file an address for service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant's response is continued under subrule (18) as a reply to a claim and the defendant is not the filing party, the defendant must file an address for service (Form 38) and serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Rule 3 does not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 3 does not apply in relation to a response continued as a reply under subrule (18) of this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What are a defendant's options?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant who receives a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim and who does not have a response continued as a reply under subrule (18) may do any one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pay the amount claimed directly to the claimant and ask the claimant to withdraw the claim (see Rule 8);
admit all or part of the claim;
admit all or part of the claim and propose a payment schedule (see Rule 11 (4));
oppose all or part of the claim by listing reasons why the claim is opposed;
with the permission of a judge, make a counterclaim against the claimant (see subrule (26)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How does a defendant reply?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To do anything set out in subrule (20) (b) to (e), a defendant must complete a reply (Form 2) and an address for service (Form 38), following the instructions on the forms.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Where does a defendant file a reply?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant must file a reply and an address for service at the registry where the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim was filed and, except where the defendant has agreed to pay all of the claim, pay the required fee.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit for replying
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim is served on a defendant, the reply must be filed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 14 days after service if the defendant was served in British Columbia or within 30 days after service if the defendant was served outside British Columbia, and
before the registrar has made a default order or set a date for a hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a reply is served
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Within 21 days after a reply and an address for service are filed under subrule (22), the registrar must serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How an admission is accepted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant admits in a reply all or part of the claim, the claimant may accept the admission in full settlement of the claim, interest and expenses by filing, before the settlement conference or trial conference, a payment order in the same terms as the admission.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Making a Claim Against a Claimant

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions on making a counterclaim if proceeding started by notice of civil resolution tribunal claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 4 does not apply to a defendant if the proceeding was started by a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, unless the defendant has the permission of a judge to make a counterclaim (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claim made before civil resolution tribunal continued as a counterclaim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claim made by a defendant against a claimant and set out in an initiating notice filed under subrule (8) with a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim is continued as a counterclaim made under these rules against the claimant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Rule 4 does not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 4 does not apply in relation to a claim continued as a counterclaim under subrule (27) of this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Previous response continued as a reply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A response made by a claimant is continued as a reply to a counterclaim if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claimant made a response in respect of a claim when the claim was proceeding before the civil resolution tribunal as a tribunal small claim,
the response is filed under subrule (8) with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, and
the claim is continued as a counterclaim under subrule (27).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Rule 3 does not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 3 does not apply in relation to a response continued as a reply under subrule (29) of this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What are the claimant's options?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a counterclaim against a claimant is continued under subrule (27) and the claimant did not have a response continued as a reply under subrule (29), the claimant may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pay the amount of the counterclaim directly to the defendant and ask the defendant to withdraw the counterclaim;
admit all or part of the counterclaim;
admit all or part of the counterclaim and propose a payment schedule (see Rule 11 (4));
oppose all or part of the counterclaim by listing reasons why the counterclaim is opposed.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a claimant replies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To do anything set out in subrule (31) (b) to (d), a claimant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a reply (Form 2) and an address for service following the instructions on the forms,
file the reply and the address for service (Form 38),

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if the claimant is the filing party, with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, or
if the claimant is not the filing party and the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim is served on the claimant,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: within 14 days after service if the claimant was served in British Columbia or within 30 days after service if the claimant was served outside British Columbia, and
before the registrar has made a default order or set a date for a hearing, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pay the required fee unless the claimant has agreed to pay all of the counterclaim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a reply is served
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Within 21 days after a reply and an address for service are filed under subrule (32), the registrar must serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How an admission is accepted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claimant admits in a reply all or part of a counterclaim, the defendant may accept the admission in full settlement of the counterclaim, interest and expenses by filing, before the settlement conference or trial conference, a payment order in the same terms as the admission.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions on making a third party claim if proceeding started by notice of civil resolution tribunal claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 5 does not apply to a defendant if the proceeding was started by a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, unless the defendant has the permission of a judge to make a claim against another person (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claim made to civil resolution tribunal continued as a claim against third party
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant thought that a person who was not otherwise a party to the dispute before the civil resolution tribunal was responsible for the claim, the claim made by the defendant against the other person and set out in the initiating notice filed under subrule (8) with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim is continued as a claim made under these rules against the other person as a third party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Subrules do not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 5 (1) to (7) and (9) does not apply in relation to a claim continued under subrule (36) of this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Previous response continued as a reply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A response made by a third party is continued as a reply to a claim made against the third party if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the third party made a response in respect of the claim when the claim was proceeding before the civil resolution tribunal as a tribunal small claim,
the response is filed under subrule (8) with a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, and
the claim is continued under subrule (36).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Third party must file an address for service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a response made by a third party is continued under subrule (38) as a reply to a claim made against the third party and the third party is not the filing party, the third party must file an address for service (Form 38) and serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a third party replies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a third party receives a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, does not have a response continued as a reply under subrule (38) and wishes to reply to the claim, the third party must follow subrules (20) to (23) to reply to the claim.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Deposits for Claims Previously Adjudicated by Civil Resolution Tribunal

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application for deposit by filing party
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a filing party wishes to apply for an order that a person make a deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act, the filing party must file the application with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim and serve a copy of the application with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, unless the filing party has the permission of a judge to make the application on a later date (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application for deposit by party other than filing party
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party, other than the filing party, wishes to apply for an order that a person make a deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act, the party must file the application within 14 days after service of the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim if that party was served in British Columbia or within 30 days after service of the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim if that party was served outside British Columbia, unless that party has the permission of a judge to make the application on a later date.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claimant does not make a deposit
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claimant has been ordered to make a deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act and the claimant has failed to make the deposit as ordered, a judge may dismiss the claim under Rule 16 (6) (n.2).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a defendant does not make a deposit
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant has been ordered to make a deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act and the defendant has failed to make the deposit as ordered, the claimant may ask the registrar for a default order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a third party does not make a deposit
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant under a counterclaim or under a third party notice or a third party has been ordered to make a deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act and has failed to make the deposit as ordered, no default order will be made except under Rule 16 (6) (n.3).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to ask for a default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To ask for a default order under subrule (41.11), a claimant must complete Form 5, following the instructions on the form, file it at the registry where the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim was filed and pay the required fee.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claim is for a debt
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claim is for a debt and the claimant completes the steps in subrule (41.20), the registrar must make a default order requiring the defendant to pay immediately the amount claimed plus expenses under Rule 20 (2) and any interest the claimant is entitled to.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claim is not for a debt
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claim is not for a debt and the claimant completes the steps in subrule (41.20), the registrar must set a date for a hearing before a judge.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Submit documents to registry before hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least two business days before the date of a hearing set under subrule (41.22), a claimant must file at the registry all documents on which the claimant intends to rely at the hearing, with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Purpose of hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The purpose of a hearing set under subrule (41.22) is to allow a judge to determine

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount the claimant is entitled to, if the claim is for money, and
the terms of an appropriate order, in any other case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Result of hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After hearing the claimant, the judge may,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the claim is for money, make a default order that requires the defendant to pay immediately the amount determined by the judge plus expenses under Rule 20 (2) and any interest the claimant is entitled to, and
in any other case, make the appropriate order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claimant does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claimant does not attend at the time set for a hearing under subrule (41.22), the judge may cancel the hearing, but the claimant may ask the registrar to reschedule it.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How payment may be collected
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The creditor may collect payment under a default order made under subrule (41.31) (a) by taking any of the steps listed in Rule 11 (11).

bcl:division.bcl:text: Material to be Filed before Settlement or Trial Conference

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing party must file a certificate of compliance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A filing party must file at the registry a certificate of compliance (Form 37) within 6 months after the filing party served the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim on all other parties if there is at least one reply filed or continued in respect of the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What certificate of compliance must contain
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a notice of objection was filed under Division 5 of Part 5 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act in respect of the claim, a certificate of compliance must contain one of the following statements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement that no party filed an application for deposit under subrule (40) or (41) within the period provided by the applicable subrule;
a statement that an application for a deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act was dismissed;
a statement that an application for a deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act was granted and either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the deposit has been made, or
if the court has ordered that the deposit be paid in instalments, all due instalments have been paid.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Attachments to be filed in personal injury cases
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In a claim by a filing party for damages for personal injuries, the certificate of compliance to be filed under subrule (42) must have attached copies of all

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: medical reports, and
records of expenses or losses incurred or expected.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If filing party is not ready to file certificate of compliance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A filing party who is not ready to file the certificate of compliance and attachments within the 6 month period may apply to the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)) to extend the time, before or after the 6 month period has expired.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate of compliance must be served on other parties
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Within 14 days after filing a certificate of compliance, the filing party must serve a copy of the certificate and attachments on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar must schedule settlement conference or trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar must schedule a claim for a settlement conference or a trial conference (see Rule 7 (2) (c)) after a certificate of compliance is filed under subrule (42).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate to be filed in personal injury cases
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In a claim by a party, other than the filing party, for damages for personal injuries, the party must file at the registry, within 6 months after the filing party served the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim on that party, a certificate of readiness (Form 7) that has attached copies of all

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: medical reports, and
records of expenses or losses incurred or expected.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party is not ready to file certificate of readiness
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party, other than the filing party, who is not ready to file a certificate of readiness and attachments within the 6 month period may apply to the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)) to extend the time, before or after the 6 month period has expired.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate of readiness must be served on other parties
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Within 14 days after filing a certificate of readiness, the party must serve a copy of the certificate and attachments on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Who must be served?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The claimant must serve each defendant named in the notice of claim with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant's copy of the notice,
a blank reply form (Form 2),
the claimant's address for service, and
a blank address for service form (Form 38).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve an individual
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant is an individual, the notice of claim must be served by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: leaving a copy of it with the defendant, or
mailing a copy of it by registered mail to the defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve a company
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant is a company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act, the notice of claim must be served,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the company has a registered office,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by delivering a copy of the notice of claim to the delivery address shown for that registered office in the office of the Registrar of Companies, or
by mailing a copy of the notice of claim by registered mail to the mailing address shown for that registered office in the office of the Registrar of Companies,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the company's registered office has been eliminated, in the manner ordered by the court, or
in either case, by leaving a copy of the notice of claim

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at the place of business of the company, with a receptionist or a person who appears to manage or control the company's business there, or
with a director, officer, liquidator, trustee in bankruptcy or receiver manager of the company.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve an extraprovincial company
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant is an extraprovincial company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act, the notice of claim must be served

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by delivering a copy of it to the delivery address shown for the head office of the extraprovincial company in the office of the Registrar of Companies if that head office is in British Columbia,

by mailing a copy of it by registered mail to the mailing address shown for the head office of the extraprovincial company in the office of the Registrar of Companies if that head office is in British Columbia,

by mailing a copy of it by registered mail to the mailing address shown in the office of the Registrar of Companies for any attorney appointed for the extraprovincial company under Division 2 of Part 11 of the Business Corporations Act,
by leaving a copy of it with the attorney, or
if no attorney has been appointed, by following subrule (3) (c).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve a partnership
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant is a partnership, the notice of claim must be served by mailing a copy of it by registered mail to a partner, or by leaving a copy of it

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with a partner,
at a place of business of the partnership, with a person who appears to manage or control the partnership business there, or
with a receptionist who works at a place of business of the partnership.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Other service rules — see Rule 18
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The provisions in Rule 18 apply if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant is a municipality, a person under 19, a society, an extraprovincial non-share corporation within the meaning of the Societies Act or an unincorporated association including a trade union,
the claimant needs to serve the notice of claim on a person outside British Columbia, or
the claimant is having difficulty serving the defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit for service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a notice of claim has not been served within 12 months after it was filed it expires, but the claimant may apply to have it renewed (see Rule 16 (3)).

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Replying to a Claim Made by a Notice of Claim

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What are a defendant's options?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant who receives a notice of claim may do any one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pay the amount claimed directly to the claimant and ask the claimant to withdraw the claim (see Rule 8);
admit all or part of the claim;
admit all or part of the claim and propose a payment schedule (see Rule 11 (4));
oppose all or part of the claim by listing reasons why the claim is opposed;
make a counterclaim against the claimant (see Rule 4).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How does a defendant reply?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To do anything set out in subrule (1) (b) to (e), a defendant must complete a reply (Form 2) and an address for service (Form 38), following the instructions on the forms.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Where does a defendant file a reply?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant must file a reply and an address for service at the registry where the notice of claim was filed and, except where the defendant has agreed to pay all of the claim, pay the required fee.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit for replying
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a notice of claim is served on a defendant, the reply must be filed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 14 days after service if the defendant was served in British Columbia or within 30 days after service if the defendant was served outside British Columbia, and
before the registrar has made a default order or set a date for a hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a reply is served
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Within 21 days after a reply and an address for service are filed, the registrar must serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How an admission is accepted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant admits in a reply all or part of the claim, the claimant may accept the admission in full settlement of the claim, interest and expenses by filing, before the settlement conference, mediation session or trial conference, a payment order in the same terms as the admission.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Making a Claim Against a Claimant

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Making a counterclaim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to Rule 1.1 (26), a defendant may make a counterclaim against the claimant in the reply (Form 2) by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: following the instructions on the form, and
paying the required fee.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a counterclaim is served
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A counterclaim is served on a claimant when a copy of the reply containing the counterclaim is served under Rule 3 (5).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What are the claimant's options?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claimant who is served with a reply containing a counterclaim may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pay the amount of the counterclaim directly to the defendant and ask the defendant to withdraw the counterclaim;
admit all or part of the counterclaim;
admit all or part of the counterclaim and propose a payment schedule (see Rule 11 (4));
oppose all or part of the counterclaim by listing reasons why the counterclaim is opposed.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a claimant replies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To do anything set out in subrule (3) (b) to (d), a claimant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a reply (Form 2) following the instructions on the form,
within 14 days after being served with the counterclaim, file the reply in the registry where the notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim was filed, and
pay the required fee unless the claimant has agreed to pay all of the counterclaim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How an admission is accepted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claimant admits in a reply all or part of a counterclaim, the defendant may accept the admission in full settlement of the counterclaim, interest and expenses by filing, before the settlement conference, mediation session or trial conference, a payment order in the same terms as the admission.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a counterclaim is for more than $35 000
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant who has a counterclaim amounting to more than $35 000, not including interest and expenses, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: abandon part of the counterclaim so it may be heard in the court, or
begin an action in the Supreme Court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to abandon part of a counterclaim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To abandon part of a counterclaim, the defendant must say on the counterclaim part of the reply that the amount over $35 000 is abandoned.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of abandoning part of a counterclaim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant who abandons part of a counterclaim may not at any time sue for that part.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a defendant begins a Supreme Court action
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant who begins an action in the Supreme Court against a claimant may apply to a Provincial Court judge for an order changing the date of the small claims trial (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the small claims trial is held first
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the small claims trial is held and a payment order or other order is made against the defendant, the judge may order the claimant not to take any action to enforce the order

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: until a date set by the judge, or
until a decision is given by the Supreme Court on the defendant's action,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: whichever comes first.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claimant has already abandoned part of a claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant begins an action in the Supreme Court against a claimant who has abandoned part of a claim under Rule 1 (5), the claimant may withdraw the claim from the Provincial Court and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: begin an action in the Supreme Court and claim the higher amount, or
participate in the action begun by the defendant in the Supreme Court and claim the higher amount.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a defendant thinks someone else should pay the claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to Rule 1.1 (35), if a defendant who has filed a reply thinks another person should pay all or part of the claim, the defendant may make a claim against the other person by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: completing a third party notice (Form 3), following the instructions on the form if a settlement conference has not been held, or
applying to a judge for an order permitting a claim to be made against the other person if a settlement conference, mediation session or trial conference has been held (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing a third party notice
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The defendant must file a third party notice at the registry where the notice of claim or the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim was filed and pay the required fee.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the third party is a company
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the third party is a company within the meaning of the Business Corporations Act, the defendant must file with the third party notice a printout of a search showing the mailing address that is shown for the company's registered office in the office of the Registrar of Companies.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the third party is a society
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the third party is a society within the meaning of the Societies Act, the defendant must file with the third party notice a printout of a search showing the delivery address and mailing address of the society's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What documents must be served on the third party?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The defendant must serve the person named as the third party with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the third party notice;
a blank reply form;
a copy of the notice of claim or the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim;
a copy of the reply to the notice of claim or the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim;
a copy of the notice of settlement conference, mediation session, trial conference or trial, if one has been issued;
a copy of the documents referred to in Rule 1.1 (8) (a) and (b), if a copy of the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim must be served on the person named as the third party;
a blank address for service form (Form 38);
a copy of each party's address for service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve the third party
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The defendant must serve the documents referred to in subrule (3) on the third party in the same way as required for service of a notice of claim (see Rule 2).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing a certificate of service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Within 30 days after filing a third party notice, the defendant must file a certificate of service (Form 4) at the registry to prove that the documents have been served as required, unless the third party has filed a reply.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a certificate of service is not filed within 30 days
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a certificate of service is not filed in accordance with subrule (5), the third party notice expires but the defendant may apply to have it renewed (see Rule 16 (3)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notifying the other parties
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar must serve a copy of the third party notice on each of the other parties within 21 days after it is filed.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a third party replies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To reply to a third party notice, the person named as a third party must follow the rules for replying to a claim (see Rule 3), except that instead of filing a reply (Form 2), the third party must file a reply to third party notice (Form 3.1).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a judge may do
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a third party has been named, a judge may make an order between any of the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Another settlement conference must be held
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a third party files a reply after a settlement conference or trial conference another settlement conference or trial conference must be held, unless a judge orders otherwise.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: If a Defendant Does Not Reply to a Claim

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: A claimant may ask for a default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant does not file a reply within the time limit (see Rule 3 (4) or 1.1 (23)), the claimant may ask the registrar for a default order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge's permission needed in certain cases
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: No default order will be made on a counterclaim or third party notice, except under Rule 16 (6) (c).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to ask for a default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To ask for a default order under subrule (1), a claimant must complete Form 5, following the instructions on the form, file it at the registry where the notice of claim or the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim was filed, together with a copy of the certificate of service (Form 4) for the notice of claim or the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, and pay the required fee.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claim is for a debt
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claim is for a debt and the claimant completes the steps in subrule (3), the registrar must make a default order requiring the defendant to pay immediately the amount claimed plus expenses under Rule 20 (2) and any interest the claimant is entitled to.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claim is not for a debt
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claim is not for a debt and the claimant completes the steps in subrule (3), the registrar must set a date for a hearing before a judge.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Submit documents to registry before hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least two business days before the date of a hearing set under subrule (5), a claimant must file at the registry all documents on which the claimant intends to rely at the hearing, with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If there are other defendants
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If any other defendant has filed a reply and a date is set for a settlement conference, trial conference or trial of the claim, the hearing must be held at that time, unless a judge orders otherwise.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: No notice of hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant who has not filed a reply is not entitled to receive notice of a hearing under this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: A defendant loses the right to reply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After a date is set for a hearing under this rule, a defendant may not file a reply without the permission of a judge (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Purpose of hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The purpose of a hearing under this rule is to allow a judge to determine

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount the claimant is entitled to, if the claim is for money, and
the terms of an appropriate order, in any other case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Result of hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After hearing the claimant, the judge may,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the claim is for money, make a default order that requires the defendant to pay immediately the amount determined by the judge plus expenses under Rule 20 (2) and any interest the claimant is entitled to, and
in any other case, make the appropriate order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claimant does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claimant does not attend at the time set for a hearing under this rule, the judge may cancel the hearing, but the claimant may ask the registrar to reschedule it.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How payment may be collected
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The creditor may collect payment under a default order by taking any of the steps listed in Rule 11 (11).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Settlement conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Before a trial date is set, a settlement conference will be held at the time and place set by the registrar.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Settlement conference not required
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrule (1), a settlement conference will not be held if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Rule 9.1 or 9.2 applies to the claim, unless an order is made under Rule 9.2 (13) (c) that the claim be set for a settlement conference under this rule,
on or before April 30, 2016, Rule 7.5 applied to the claim,
the claim relates to a motor vehicle accident and only liability for property damage is disputed, or
all of the following apply in relation to the claim:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the proceeding was started by a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim;

the civil resolution tribunal gave a final decision under section 46 (1) (a) of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act in relation to the claim unless one of the parties did not make a response under section 7 of that Act;
a certificate referred to in Rule 1.1 (8) (b) (i) was filed with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Some motor vehicle accident cases proceed directly to trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If subrule (2) (b) applies to the claim, the registrar must set the claim for trial and send a notice of trial to the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Some cases proceed directly to trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar must set the claim for a trial conference if subrule (2) (c) applies to the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of settlement conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar must serve a notice of settlement conference (Form 6) on the parties at least 28 days before the date set for the settlement conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Who must attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: All parties must attend the settlement conference and have authority to settle the claim, and may be accompanied by a lawyer or articled student, except the defendant need not attend if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claim results from a motor vehicle accident,
the defendant is disputing the amount of the claim but not liability, and
a person appointed by the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia attends instead of the defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Relevant documents and reports
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Each party to a claim must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submit all relevant documents and reports to the registry at least 14 days before the date of the settlement conference, and
serve all relevant documents and reports on the other parties at least 7 days before the date of the settlement conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Expenses for attending settlement conference unprepared
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a settlement conference cannot be conducted properly because a party is not prepared for it, a judge may order that party to pay the reasonable expenses of the other party or parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to change a settlement conference date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may change a settlement conference date by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filing a consent to change the date under Rule 16 (1), or

applying for an order changing the date of the settlement conference at least 7 days before the date set for the settlement conference, unless the registrar orders otherwise, and giving whatever notice to the other party that the registrar or judge requires.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of change of date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the date of the settlement conference is changed, the registrar must notify the parties of the place and time of the rescheduled conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate to be filed in personal injury cases
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claim is for damages for personal injuries and the proceeding was started by a notice of claim, the claimant must file at the registry, within 6 months after serving the notice of claim and before a settlement conference is held, a certificate of readiness (Form 7) that has attached copies of all

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: medical reports, and
records of expenses or losses incurred or expected.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the claimant is not ready to file certificate
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claimant who is not ready to file the certificate of readiness and attachments within the 6 month period may apply to the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)) to extend the time, before or after the 6 month period has expired.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate must be served on other parties
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Within 14 days after filing a certificate of readiness, the claimant must serve a copy of the certificate and attachments on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Defendant may request a medical report
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant in a claim for damages for personal injuries may apply to a judge (see Rule 16 (7)) to order the claimant to attend a medical practitioner or another person who is authorized under the Health Professions Act to practise a designated health profession for an examination, to be paid for by the defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Report to be given to claimant and provided to registry
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After receiving the medical report from the medical practitioner or other person authorized under the Health Professions Act to practise a designated health profession, the defendant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submit the report to the registry at least 14 days before the date of the settlement conference, and
serve a copy of the report on the claimant at least 7 days before the date of the settlement conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What happens at a settlement conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At a settlement conference, a judge may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mediate any issues being disputed;
decide on any issues that do not require evidence;
make a payment order or other appropriate order in the terms agreed to by the parties;
order that the claim be set for a trial conference under Rule 7.5;
set a trial date, if a trial is necessary;
discuss any evidence that will be required and the procedure that will be followed if a trial is necessary;
order a party to produce any information at the settlement conference or anything as evidence at trial;
order a party to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: give another party copies of documents and records by a set date, or
allow another party to inspect and copy documents and records by a set date;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if damage to property is involved in the dispute, order a party to permit a person chosen by another party to examine the property damage;
dismiss a claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice if, after discussion with the parties and reviewing the filed documents, a judge determines that it

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is without reasonable grounds,
discloses no triable issue, or
is frivolous or an abuse of the court's process;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before dismissing a claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice, order a party to file an affidavit setting out further information;
order that a trial is to be attended by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 148/97, s. 7 (e).]
make any other order for the just, speedy and inexpensive resolution of the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If settlement conference judge orders parties to attend trial by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge at a settlement conference orders that a trial is to be attended by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication, the judge must also direct how, and by what date, to submit and serve any records and other things on which a party intends to rely at trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not comply with a disclosure order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party does not comply with an order under subrule (14) (f), (g), (h) or (j), a judge may at any time do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjourn a settlement conference or trial and order that party to pay all the reasonable expenses incurred by any other parties as a result of the adjournment;
order a trial to proceed without permitting that party to produce as evidence any information, document or records withheld as a result of the non-compliance;
dismiss the claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a payment order is made
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a payment order is made at a settlement conference, Rule 11 (Payment of the Judgment) applies as though the payment order was made following a trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may dismiss the claim or make a payment order or other appropriate order against a party who does not attend a settlement conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of trial date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a trial date is set at a settlement conference and a party is absent, the registrar must serve a notice of the trial date on that party unless the judge orders otherwise.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Place of the trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: All further steps in the claim, including the trial, will take place where the settlement conference is held except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a judge orders otherwise, or
as provided in Rule 16 (11) and Rule 17 (8).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not comply with a settlement agreement
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a settlement is recorded on the court record as an agreement and not as a payment order and a party does not comply with the recorded terms of the agreement,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the agreement is cancelled, and

after filing an affidavit of non-compliance, the claimant may file a payment order in the amount that a judge directed at the settlement conference or, if no direction was made, in the amount of the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Settlement conference — transition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a notice of settlement conference is dated October 2, 2022 or earlier, and if the settlement conference is scheduled to take place on or after October 3, 2022, the following rules apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: despite Rule 7 (5), the parties must submit all relevant documents and reports to the registry at least two business days before the date of the settlement conference, and are not required to serve all relevant documents and reports on the other parties before the settlement conference;
despite Rule 7 (13) (a), the defendant must submit the medical report referred to in Rule 7 (13) to the registry at least two business days before the date of the settlement conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Transfer of claim to Supreme Court
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If satisfied that the monetary outcome of a claim (not including interest and expenses) may exceed $35 000, a judge must transfer the claim to the Supreme Court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on application at any time, or
on the judge's own motion at the settlement conference or trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Exception
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrule (1), a claim must not be transferred to the Supreme Court if the claimant chooses to abandon the amount over $35 000 so that the claim may be heard in the Provincial Court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Personal injury claims
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Before transferring a claim for personal injury to the Supreme Court, a judge must consider any medical reports or records filed by the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Multiple claims
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If more than one claimant has filed a notice of claim or a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim against the same defendant or defendants with respect to the same event, or if one claimant has filed notices of claim or notices of civil resolution tribunal claim against more than one defendant with respect to the same event, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hear at one time evidence that relates to all the claims,
apply that evidence to all the claims, and
make a decision in each of the claims,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: even though the total monetary outcome of all the claims (not including interest and expenses) is likely to exceed $35 000.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite the repeal of Rule 7.2, Rules 7.2 (27) to (29), (31) to (33) and (35) to (37) and 16 (6) (f.2) and (j), as they read on December 31, 2018, continue to apply in relation to a mediation session to which Rule 7.2 applied.
