bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: insurer has the same meaning as in the Insurance Act, and includes the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia;
mediation means a collaborative process in which 2 or more parties meet and attempt, with the assistance of a mediator, to resolve issues in dispute between them;
mediation session means a meeting between 2 or more parties during which they are engaged in mediation for a period of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 2 hours,
any shorter period that the mediator may direct, or
any shorter or longer period on which the parties may agree;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: mediator means a neutral and impartial facilitator with no decision making power who assists parties in negotiating a mutually acceptable settlement of issues in dispute between them;

motor vehicle action means a proceeding in which damages are claimed for injury or death, or loss of or damage to property, that arises out of the use or operation of a motor vehicle or trailer as those terms are defined in the Motor Vehicle Act;

party, in relation to a proceeding, includes an insurer of a claimant, defendant or third party if that insurer has a duty to do one or both of the following in relation to the claimant, defendant or third party:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: indemnify that party for liability arising out of a claim in the proceeding;
defend any claims made against that party in the proceeding;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: roster organization means any body designated by the Attorney General to select mediators for the purposes of this rule;
third party means a person who is named as a third party under Rule 5, but does not include an insurer who has been made a third party under section 76 of the Insurance (Vehicle) Act;
third party insurer means, in relation to a designated action, an insurer that has been made a third party in an action under section 76 of the Insurance (Vehicle) Act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Proceedings to which this rule applies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (3), a party to a proceeding may initiate mediation in that proceeding under subrule (5) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the notice of claim that started the proceeding was filed after August 31, 2005, and
a claim in the proceeding amounts to more than $10 000 and not more than $35 000, without taking into account interest or claim-related expenses.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claims to which this rule does not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party to a proceeding may not initiate mediation in that proceeding under subrule (5) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proceeding involves a party who has obtained one of the following against another party:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a protection order under section 183 of the Family Law Act;
a peace bond under section 810 of the Criminal Code,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Rule 9.2 applies to a claim in the proceeding, or
the claimant, defendant and cause of action in the proceeding are the same as the plaintiff, defendant and cause of action in an action brought in the Supreme Court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When this rule ceases to apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule ceases to apply to a proceeding if the proceeding is transferred to the Supreme Court under Rule 7.1.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Initiating mediation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (7), any party to a proceeding may initiate mediation by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filing a Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 (Form 29), and
delivering a copy of that filed notice to every other party named on a notice of claim, reply or third party notice that has been filed in the proceeding.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 must be delivered
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court orders otherwise, a Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 must not be filed and delivered under subrule (5) until a reply has been filed in the proceeding.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Not more than one mediation under this rule in any proceeding
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, not more than one mediation may be initiated under this rule in relation to any proceeding.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Rule does not apply unless mediation is initiated under subrules (5) and (6)
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subrules (9) to (53) do not apply to a proceeding unless mediation is initiated in that proceeding under subrule (5).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment of mediator
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The parties must jointly appoint a mutually acceptable mediator within 14 days after the Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 has been delivered to all parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to roster organization
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the parties do not jointly appoint a mutually acceptable mediator within the time required by subrule (9), any party may apply to a roster organization for an appointment of a mediator.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Roster organization's appointment procedure
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an application to a roster organization is made under subrule (10), the roster organization must select a mediator after taking into account

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the need for the mediator to be neutral and independent,
the qualifications of the mediator,
the mediator's fees,
the mediator's availability,
the nature of the dispute, and
any other consideration likely to result in the selection of an impartial, competent and effective mediator.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notification of selection of mediator
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Promptly after selecting a mediator under subrule (11), the roster organization must notify the parties in writing of that selection.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Deemed date of appointment of mediator
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The mediator selected under subrule (11) is deemed to be appointed by the parties on the date that notice of that selection is sent under subrule (12).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Replacement of appointed mediator
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the mediator selected by the roster organization under subrule (11) is unable or unwilling to act as mediator,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the selected mediator or any party may notify the roster organization of that inability or unwillingness, and
the roster organization must, within 7 days after receiving that notice, select a new mediator in accordance with subrule (11).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Mediator's role
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The mediator may conduct the mediation session at the location and in any manner the mediator considers appropriate to assist the parties to reach a resolution that is fair, timely and cost-effective.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Scheduling of mediation session
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A mediation session must occur within 60 days after the appointment of the mediator, and at least 7 days before the date set under Rule 7 for the settlement conference unless a later specified date

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is agreed on by all parties and that agreement is confirmed by the mediator in writing, or
is ordered by the court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Attending the mediation session
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In the case of a claim that is not a motor vehicle action,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party who delivers a Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 under subrule (5) and each of the following parties must attend the mediation session unless exempted from attending under subrule (29):

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the claimant;
the defendant;
the third party, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each insurer of a claimant, defendant or third party may attend the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Attending the mediation session in a motor vehicle action
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In the case of a motor vehicle action, the party who delivers a Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 under subrule (5) and each of the following parties must attend the mediation session unless exempted from attending under subrule (29):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claimant;
the insurer of the defendant or, if the defendant is not insured, the defendant;
the insurer of the third party or, if the third party is not insured, the third party;
each third party insurer to the action.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Requirements on parties who attend mediation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Each person who attends a mediation session must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have authority to settle, and
before the mediation session, provide to the mediator and serve on the other parties all documents and reports that are relevant to the dispute.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Representative may attend for any party who is not an individual
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may attend a mediation session by representative if the party is not an individual.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Authority of representative
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A representative who attends a mediation session under subrule (20) in the place of a party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be familiar with all facts relevant to the dispute, and

have full authority to settle, or have access at the earliest practicable opportunity to a person who has, or to a group of persons who collectively have, full authority to settle, on behalf of the party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Party or representative may be accompanied by a lawyer
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person or representative who attends a mediation session may be accompanied by a lawyer or articled student.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Other persons may attend with consent
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Any other person may attend a mediation session if that attendance is permitted by the mediator and consented to by the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Attending a mediation session by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: One or more of the persons who are required or permitted to attend a mediation session under subrule (17), (18) or (23) may attend the mediation session by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all of the other persons attending the mediation session consent, or
subject to subrule (26), the registrar authorizes that attendance under subrule (25).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to attend mediation by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may authorize one or more persons who are required or permitted to attend a mediation session under subrule (17), (18) or (23) to attend the mediation session by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication if an application for that authorization is made to the registrar under Rule 16 (3) at least 7 days before the date set for the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Late application to attend mediation by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an application for an authorization under subrule (25) is made to the registrar under Rule 16 (3) within 7 days before the date set for the mediation session, the registrar may make that authorization if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it was not reasonably practicable for that person to bring an application under subrule (25) at least 7 days before the date set for the mediation session, or
exceptional circumstances exist.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If application is granted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an application under subrule (25) or (26) is granted, the registrar may order the person requesting to attend the mediation by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication to pay for the telephone call, video conference or other cost of that person's attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for exemption
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 14 days before the date set for the mediation session, a party may apply to a judge under Rule 16 (7) to exempt a claim from the application of this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a judge may grant an exemption
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On an application under subrule (28), a judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempt a claim from the application of this rule if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: all of the parties have previously engaged in a mediation of the matters in issue, or
it is unfair or impractical to require mediation, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempt one or more of the parties from attending the mediation session if, in the judge's opinion, it is unfair or impractical to require the party to attend.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Adjourning a mediation session
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 7 days before the date set for the mediation session, a party may apply to the registrar to adjourn the mediation session and that party must give to the other parties whatever notice of the application the registrar may order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Date may be changed to avoid hardship
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may adjourn a mediation session under subrule (30) if the party applying for that adjournment satisfies the registrar that the original date is unreasonably inconvenient to the party, and, without limiting this, the registrar may determine that a date is unreasonably inconvenient to a party if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family emergency renders the party unable to attend on the day set for the mediation session, or
the party is required to attend court on the day set for the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of change of date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the registrar adjourns a mediation session under subrule (31),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party who applied for the adjournment must give to the other parties whatever notice of the adjournment the registrar may order, and
the parties must jointly set a new date, satisfactory to the mediator, for the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Fee declaration
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The parties who attend the mediation session must complete and sign a fee declaration (Form 30) before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Corporation may sign by representative
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of subrule (33), a party that is a corporation may sign the fee declaration by its representative.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Form of fee declaration
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A fee declaration under subrule (33) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: disclose the cost of the mediation services, and
contain a declaration by the parties signing the fee declaration that the costs of the mediation will be paid

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: equally by all of the following who attend the mediation session or their insurers:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: each claimant;
each defendant;
each third party, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on any other basis that has been agreed to by those parties and is specified in the fee declaration.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Costs may be paid on a different basis
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The cost of the mediation must be paid on the basis set out

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the fee declaration, or

if the parties who signed the fee declaration agree to a different basis for sharing that cost and that basis is included in the mediation agreement referred to in subrule (48) (b), on the basis included in the mediation agreement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party who is required to attend a mediation session does not attend the mediation session or does not sign a fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mediator must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: complete a verification of default (Form 31) in accordance with the instructions on the form, and
give the completed form to the parties attending, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any one of the parties attending the mediation session may file the completed verification of default at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the registrar will do if a claimant does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a verification of default is filed in relation to a claimant in a proceeding,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant in the proceeding may, by filing a request for judgment or for dismissal (Form 23) and paying the required fee, ask the registrar to make an order dismissing the claimant's claim, and
the registrar may make an order dismissing the claimant's claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a defendant or insurer does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A verification of default may be filed in relation to a defendant, including, without limitation, a defendant to a counterclaim and a defendant to a third party notice, in the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a motor vehicle action in relation to which the defendant is insured, a verification of default may be filed in relation to the defendant if the insurer of the defendant did not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: attend the mediation session, or
sign the fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a motor vehicle action in relation to which the defendant is not insured, a verification of default may be filed in relation to the defendant if the defendant did not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: attend the mediation session, or
sign the fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a motor vehicle action in relation to which there is a third party insurer, a verification of default may be filed in relation to the defendant if the third party insurer did not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: attend the mediation session, or
sign the fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in any other case, a verification of default may be filed in relation to the defendant if the defendant did not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: attend the mediation session, or
sign the fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application for default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The following apply if a verification of default is filed under subrule (39):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the verification of default is filed in relation to a defendant who is named as a defendant on the notice of claim,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the claimant may, by filing a request for judgment or for dismissal and paying the required fee, ask the registrar to proceed under these rules as if the defendant had not filed a reply and the claimant had completed the steps in Rule 6 (3), and
the registrar must either make a default order under Rule 6 (4) or set a date under Rule 6 (5) for a hearing before a judge;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the verification of default is filed in relation to a defendant to a counterclaim or a defendant to a third party notice, the party bringing the counterclaim or third party notice may apply under Rule 16 (7) for a default order under Rule 16 (6) (c).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If no party attends
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If no party attends a mediation session,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mediator must complete a verification of default in accordance with the instructions on the form, and file the completed form at the registry, and
the registrar must make an order dismissing each disputed claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of a dismissal or default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party against whom an order is made under subrule (38) (b), (39) (b) or (41) (b) for not attending a mediation session or for not signing a fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session may apply under Rule 16 (7) to a judge to cancel the order, and the judge may cancel the order under Rule 16 (6) (j).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What application must contain
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party seeking an order under subrule (42) must attach to the application an affidavit containing the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the reason for not attending the mediation session or for failing to sign the fee declaration;
the reason for any delay, if there has been delay in filing the application;
the facts that support the claim or defence.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a judge cancels a dismissal or default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge who cancels a dismissal order or default order made under this rule may also do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that the disputed claims proceed to mediation on any terms the judge considers appropriate;
order the payment of any expenses incurred by the party or parties who did attend;
order that a settlement conference or trial be held;
make any other order that the judge considers appropriate in the circumstances.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Disclosure and compellability
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrules (46) and (47), a person must not disclose, or be compelled to disclose, in any proceeding oral or written information acquired in or in connection with a mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Exceptions
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subrule (45) does not apply

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in respect of any information, opinion, document, offer or admission that all of the parties agree in writing may be disclosed,
to any mediation agreement or fee declaration made during or in connection with a mediation session,
to any threats of bodily harm made during or in connection with a mediation session, or
to any information that does not identify the parties and that is disclosed for research or statistical purposes only.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: No restriction on otherwise producible information
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Nothing in this rule precludes a party from introducing into evidence in any proceeding any information or records produced in the course of the mediation that are otherwise producible or compellable in those proceedings.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the parties reach agreement on all or some issues
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the parties reach an agreement at mediation on all or some issues,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mediator must complete a result of mediation form (Form 24) and file the completed form at the registry, and
the parties must complete and sign a mediation agreement (Form 25) and any one of those parties may file the agreement at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If payment terms are not complied with
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party fails to comply with a provision of a filed mediation agreement, the party not in default may, if that provision required a payment of money,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file an affidavit of non-compliance at the registry, and
after that, file a payment order at the registry for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the amount specified in the mediation agreement less any amount already paid in compliance with the mediation agreement, or
if no amount was specified in the mediation agreement, for the amount of the claim less any amount already paid in compliance with the mediation agreement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If other terms are not complied with
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party fails to comply with a provision of a filed mediation agreement and that provision was not one requiring a payment of money, the party not in default may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the mediation agreement establishes an amount of liquidated damages that is to be payable in the event of such a default, file at the registry an affidavit of non-compliance and a payment order for that amount, or
if the mediation agreement does not establish a liquidated damages amount in relation to the breached provision, seek a mediation compensation order (Form 26) under Rule 16 (6) (f.2).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Mediation compensation order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may make a mediation compensation order under subrule (50) (b) if a party applies for that order (see Rule 16 (7)) and attaches to the application an affidavit of non-compliance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a dispute is not resolved
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the parties do not reach agreement at mediation on all the issues,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mediator must complete a result of mediation form and file the completed form at the registry, and
after that, the registrar must set one of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: subject to subparagraph (iii), a settlement conference, if a settlement conference has not been completed;
a trial, if a settlement conference has been completed;
a trial conference, if the completed result of mediation form is filed at the Robson Square Small Claims Registry after November 25, 2007.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Concluding a mediation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A mediation is concluded when

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all issues are resolved, or
the mediator terminates the mediation.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule applies to a claim that must be set for a trial conference if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the parties do not reach agreement at mediation on all the issues (see Rule 7.3 (52)),

an order is made under Rule 7 (14) (c.1) or 9.2 (13) (c), or

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Before a trial date is set, unless the setting of a trial date is otherwise ordered by a judge, a trial conference will be held on the date and at the time and place set by the registrar.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar must serve a notice of trial conference (Form 32) on the parties at least 30 days before the date set for the trial conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Changing a trial conference date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may change the date of a trial conference

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by filing a consent to change the date under Rule 16 (1), or
by applying to the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)) for an order changing the date of the trial conference and giving to the other party whatever notice of the application the registrar may order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to change date at least 7 days before trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On an application made at least 7 days before the date set for the trial conference, the registrar may change the date of the trial conference if the registrar is satisfied that the original date is unreasonably inconvenient to the party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to change date within 7 days before trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On an application made within 7 days before the date set for the trial conference, the registrar may change the date of the trial conference if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrar is satisfied that the original date is unreasonably inconvenient to the party, and

the application contains an explanation, satisfactory to the registrar, as to why it was not reasonably practicable for the party to bring an application at least 7 days before the date sent for the trial conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Unreasonably inconvenient
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of subrules (5) and (6), the registrar may determine that a date is unreasonably inconvenient to a party if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family emergency renders the party unable to attend on the day set for the trial conference,
the party has a pre-arranged out-of-town commitment on the day set for the trial conference and that commitment cannot be changed due to travel requirements,
the party is required to attend court on the day set for the trial conference, or
the registrar otherwise determines that the date is unreasonably inconvenient to the party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of change of date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the registrar changes the date of a trial conference under subrule (5) or (6),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party who applied for the change of date must give to the other parties whatever notice of the change of date the registrar may order, and
the registrar must promptly set a new date for the trial conference and serve a notice of trial conference (Form 32) on the parties specifying the new date, time and place for the trial conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the parties must file before the trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 14 days before the date set for the trial conference, each party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a trial statement (Form 33) following the instructions on the form, and
file at the registry the trial statement with attached copies of all relevant documents.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Serving the trial statement on other parties
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 7 days before the date set for the trial conference, each party must serve a copy of their trial statement and attachments on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Who must attend the trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: All parties must have the individual who will be responsible for presenting their case at the trial attend the trial conference, which may be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party,
a representative of the party if the party is not an individual,
a representative of an insurer if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the party has assigned all of the party's rights relevant to the claim to the insurer, or
the insurer has a duty to do one or both of the following in relation to the party:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: indemnify that party for liability arising out of a claim in the proceeding;
defend any claims made against that party in the proceeding, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a lawyer or articling student.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a party is not required to attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party is not required to attend the trial conference if a person attends on behalf of the party in accordance with subrule (11) (b), (c) or (d).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Representative attending must have authority to settle
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person attends a trial conference on behalf of a party in accordance with subrule (11) (b), (c) or (d), a representative of the party attending the trial conference must have the authority to settle the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Lawyer or articling student may accompany attendee
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party or a representative of the party or an insurer may be accompanied by a lawyer or articled student at the trial conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Defendant may request a medical report
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant in a claim for damages for personal injuries may apply to a judge (see Rule 16 (7)) to order the claimant to attend a medical practitioner or another person who is authorized under the Health Professions Act to practise a designated health profession for an examination, to be paid for by the defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Medical report to be given to claimant and registry
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After receiving the medical report from the medical practitioner or other person authorized under the Health Professions Act to practise a designated health profession, the defendant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submit the report to the registry at least 14 days before the date of the trial conference, and
serve a copy of the report on the claimant at least 7 days before the date of the trial conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What happens at a trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At a trial conference, a judge may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: decide on any issues that do not require evidence;
mediate any issues being disputed;
make a payment order or other appropriate order in the terms agreed to by the parties;
discuss any evidence that will be required and the procedure that will be followed if a trial is necessary;
order a party to produce any information in the manner the judge considers appropriate;
make an order respecting the evidence of experts, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: requiring that a party file and serve on the other parties an expert's report, with or without the necessity of the expert attending to be questioned, on such terms as the judge may direct,
requiring the parties to secure an opinion from a jointly-retained independent expert, on such terms as the judge may direct, or
requiring the parties' experts to attend court at the same time to respond to each other;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if damage to property is involved in the dispute, order a party to permit a person chosen by another party to examine the property damage;
order

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the claimant to attend a medical practitioner or another person who is authorized under the Health Professions Act to practise a designated health profession for an examination, to be paid for by the defendant, and
the defendant

bcl:clause.bcl:text: to serve on the claimant a copy of the medical report from the medical practitioner or other person authorized under the Health Professions Act to practise a designated health profession at least 7 days before the trial date, and
to bring a copy of the medical report to the trial or submit it to the registry at least 14 days before the trial date;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an order respecting time limits for the conduct of all or part of a trial;
dismiss a claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice if, after discussion with the parties and reviewing the filed documents, a judge determines that it

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is without reasonable grounds,
discloses no triable issue, or
is frivolous or an abuse of the court's process;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: give a non-binding opinion on the probable outcome of the trial based on the materials before the judge at the trial conference;
order that a trial is to be attended by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 244/2015, Sch. 2, s. 4.]
make any other order for the just, speedy and inexpensive resolution of the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If trial conference judge orders parties to attend trial by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge at a trial conference orders that a trial is to be attended by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication, the judge must also direct how, and by what date, to submit and serve any records and other things on which a party intends to rely at trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not comply with orders made at the trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party does not comply with any order under subrule (14) (d) to (h) made at a trial conference, a judge may at any time do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjourn a trial and order that party to pay all the reasonable expenses incurred by any other parties as a result of the adjournment;
order a trial to proceed without permitting that party to produce as evidence any information, document or records withheld as a result of the non-compliance;
dismiss that party's claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a payment order is made
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a payment order is made at a trial conference, Rule 11 (Payment of the Judgment) applies as though the payment order was made following a trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a defendant or third party does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant or third party does not attend the trial conference, either themselves or by a representative, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: allow the claim, and
make a payment order or other appropriate order against that defendant or third party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claimant does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claimant does not attend the trial conference, either themselves or by a representative, the judge may dismiss the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Trial conferences — transition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite Rule 7.5 (13.2) (a), if a notice of trial conference is dated October 2, 2022 or earlier, and if the trial conference is scheduled to take place on or after October 3, 2022, the defendant is not required to submit the medical report referred to in Rule 7.5 (13.2) to the registry before the trial conference.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Changing or Withdrawing a Claim or Reply, Etc.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Any filed document may be changed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (1.1), anything in a notice of claim, reply or other document that has been filed by a party may be changed by that party

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without any permission,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at any time before the settlement conference begins, or
if a settlement conference will not be held, at any time before the earliest of the following:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 267/2018, s. 9.]
a trial conference under Rule 7.5;
a trial under Rule 9.1 or 9.2, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with the permission of a judge (see Rule 16 (7)), at any time after that.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Proceeding started by notice of civil resolution tribunal claim — any filed document may be changed with permission of judge
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a proceeding was started by a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, anything in the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, reply or other document that has been filed by a party may be changed by the party that originally completed the document with the permission of a judge (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to change a document
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: All changes must be underlined, initialled and dated on the revised document and, if there is an order authorizing the change, the document must contain a reference to it.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing and serving a revised document
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party who changes a filed document must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a copy of the revised document at the registry, and
before taking any other step in the claim, serve a copy of the revised document on each party to the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a revised document is served
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party who is served with a revised notice of claim, notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, counterclaim or third party notice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may, by following subrule (3), change a reply already filed by that party, or
may rely on a reply already filed by that party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: No default order for failure to change reply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: No default order will be made solely because a party relies on a filed reply instead of changing that reply.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Withdrawal of claim or other filed document
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may withdraw a claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice at any time by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filing a copy of the notice of withdrawal at the registry, and
promptly serving the notice on all the parties who were served with the claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 148/97, s. 9 (b).]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of withdrawing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party who withdraws a claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice may not at any time proceed with it or file another notice with respect to the claim or counterclaim without the permission of a judge (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claimant can change amount of claim up to $35 000
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claimant who filed a notice of claim before June 1, 2017 may change that notice of claim to increase the amount of the claim to an amount that is more than $25 000 and not more than $35 000, not including interest and expenses, whether or not the claimant had, in that notice of claim, abandoned part of the claim in accordance with Rule 1 (5).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Defendant can change amount of counterclaim up to $35 000
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant who filed a reply that contained a counterclaim before June 1, 2017 may change that reply to increase the amount of the counterclaim to an amount that is more than $25 000 and not more than $35 000, not including interest and expenses, whether or not the defendant had, in that reply, abandoned part of the counterclaim in accordance with Rule 4 (5).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to change amount of claim or counterclaim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In order to increase the amount of a claim under subrule (7) of this rule or the amount of a counterclaim under subrule (8), the party making that claim or counterclaim must change the notice of claim or reply in which the claim or counterclaim was made

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by complying with subrule (2), and
by attaching to the changed notice of claim or reply a separate page giving detailed reasons for the change.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When notice of claim or reply may be changed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A notice of claim or reply may be changed under subrule (9) before or after a settlement conference without the permission of a judge, but must not be changed after

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: judgment has been granted,
the claim or counterclaim has been dismissed by a judge,
a default order has been issued by a judge or a registrar, or
the claim or counterclaim has been settled.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Changed notice of claim or reply must be filed and served
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After a notice of claim or reply is changed under subrule (9), it must be filed and served in accordance with subrule (3).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Reply may but need not be filed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subrules (3.1) and (3.2) apply to a party who is served with a changed notice of claim or reply under subrule (11).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 135/2015, Sch. 2, s. 2.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a witness is told to attend court
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To summon a witness to court, a party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a summons to witness (Form 8), following the instructions on the form, and
serve a copy of the summons on the witness at least 7 days before the date the witness is required to attend.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Travelling and other attendance expenses
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At the time the summons is served, the party summoning the witness must offer the witness

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: reasonable estimated travelling expenses for a summons to appear in person, or
for a summons to appear by another method of attendance, the reasonable estimated cost of the telephone call, video conference or other method of attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Summons not always necessary
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a witness will attend court voluntarily, a summons is not necessary.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to change a witness's method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party or a witness may apply to a judge under Rule 16 (7.2) to change a witness's method of attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Trial judge may change a witness's method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The trial judge may order a witness to attend court by any method of attendance that the trial judge considers appropriate in the circumstances.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a witness served with a summons must do
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a summons to witness must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: attend court at the time and place stated on the summons, and
if the witness attends court in person, bring to court any records and other things required by the summons.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Summons may be cancelled or varied
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a summons to witness may apply to a judge (see Rule 16 (7)) who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cancel the summons if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person is not needed as a witness, or
it would be a hardship for the person to attend court, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: vary the summons to allow the witness to attend court by another method of attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a judge changes a witness's method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge changes a witness's method of attendance, the judge

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must direct the witness

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: how, and by what date, to submit and serve any records and other things, if the witness will not be attending in person, and
where or how to attend, including by providing a telephone number or video conferencing information, if applicable, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may order

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the return of any money that was provided under subrule (2), or
that the party summoning the witness pay for the witness's travelling expenses, telephone call, video conference or other reasonable estimated cost of the method of attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a summons is cancelled
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge who cancels a summons to witness may make any other order that the judge thinks is fair, including an order changing the date of a trial or other hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a witness does not obey a summons
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may issue a warrant (Form 9) for the arrest of a witness who does not attend court as required by a summons to witness if the judge is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the summons was served on the witness,
the witness was offered

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: reasonable estimated travelling expenses, or
other reasonable estimated costs of attendance by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication if the summons did not require the witness to appear in person, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: justice requires the presence of the witness.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of warrant
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a witness named in a warrant attends court voluntarily, the warrant is cancelled.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the judge or justice may do when witness appears
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the witness's evidence is still required,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a judge or justice may release the witness on conditions set by the judge or justice, or
a judge may order the witness to be detained until the witness's presence is no longer required.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Simplified Trials for Claims up to $10 000 (Pilot Project — Robson Square and Richmond Small Claims Registries)

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Definition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this rule, adjudicator means a judge or justice.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claims to which this rule applies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (3), this rule applies to a claim if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claim is made by way of a notice of claim, notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, counterclaim or third party notice and in respect of which

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a reply is filed opposing all or part of the claim, or
a response opposing all or part of the claim is continued as a reply,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount claimed in the notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim that started the proceeding is $10 000 or less (not including interest and expenses),
the amount claimed in any counterclaim is $10 000 or less (not including interest and expenses), and
one of the following applies in relation to the claim:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the claim is part of a proceeding started by a notice of claim, the amount claimed is $5 000 or less (not including amounts abandoned under this rule, interest and expenses) and, after November 25, 2007,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the notice of claim was filed at the Robson Square Small Claims Registry (Vancouver) or Richmond Small Claims Registry, or
the court file relating to the claim was transferred to the Robson Square Small Claims Registry (Vancouver) or Richmond Small Claims Registry;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the claim is part of a proceeding started by a notice of claim, the amount claimed is more than $5 000 and, on or after June 1, 2017,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the notice of claim was filed at the Robson Square Small Claims Registry (Vancouver) or Richmond Small Claims Registry, or
the court file relating to the claim was transferred to the Robson Square Small Claims Registry (Vancouver) or Richmond Small Claims Registry;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the claim is part of a proceeding started by a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim and, on or after June 1, 2017,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim was filed at the Robson Square Small Claims Registry (Vancouver) or Richmond Small Claims Registry, or
the court file relating to the claim was transferred to the Robson Square Small Claims Registry (Vancouver) or Richmond Small Claims Registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claims to which this rule does not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule does not apply to a claim if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claim is for damages for personal injury, or
Rule 9.2 applies to the claim, unless an order is made under Rule 9.2 (13) (c) that the claim be set for a trial under this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When this rule ceases to apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule ceases to apply to a claim if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the court file relating to the claim is transferred to another registry, or
the notice of claim, notice of civil resolution tribunal claim or reply is changed to increase the amount of the claim or counterclaim to more than $10 000, not including interest and expenses.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the claim is for more than $10 000
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claimant who has a claim amounting to more than $10 000, not including interest and expenses, may abandon part of the claim so that the balance of the claim may be heard under this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to abandon part of a claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To abandon part of a claim, a claimant must say on the notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim that the amount over $10 000 is abandoned.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of abandoning part of a claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (10.1) or (11), a claimant who abandons part of a claim under subrule (6) may not at any time sue for that part.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a counterclaim is for more than $10 000
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant who has a counterclaim amounting to more than $10 000, not including interest and expenses, may abandon part of the claim so it may be heard under this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to abandon part of a counterclaim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To abandon part of a counterclaim, the defendant must say on the counterclaim part of the reply that the amount over $10 000 is abandoned.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of abandoning part of a counterclaim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (10.2), a defendant who abandons part of a counterclaim may not at any time sue for that part.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claimant can change amount of claim up to $10 000
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claimant who filed a notice of claim before June 1, 2017 and abandoned part of the claim so that the balance of the claim may be heard under this rule may change that notice of claim to increase the amount of the claim to an amount that is more than $5 000 and not more than $10 000, not including interest and expenses, whether or not the claimant had, in that notice of claim, abandoned part of the claim in accordance with subrule (6).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Defendant can change amount of counterclaim up to $10 000
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant who filed a reply that contained a counterclaim before June 1, 2017 and abandoned part of the claim so that the balance of the claim may be heard under this rule may change that reply to increase the amount of the counterclaim to an amount that is more than $5 000 and not more than $10 000, not including interest and expenses, whether or not the defendant had, in that reply, abandoned part of the counterclaim in accordance with subrule (9).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to change amount of claim or counterclaim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In order to increase the amount of a claim under subrule (10.1) or the amount of a counterclaim under subrule (10.2), the party making that claim or counterclaim must change the notice of claim or reply in which the claim or counterclaim was made

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by complying with Rule 8 (2), and
by attaching to the changed notice of claim or reply a separate page giving detailed reasons for the change.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When notice of claim or reply must not be changed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A notice of claim or reply must not be changed after

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: judgment has been granted,
the claim or counterclaim has been dismissed by a judge,
a default order has been issued by a judge or a registrar, or
the claim or counterclaim has been settled.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Changed notice of claim or reply must be filed and served
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After a notice of claim or reply is changed under subrule (10.3), it must be filed and served in accordance with Rule 8 (3).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Reply may but need not be filed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 8 (3.1) and (3.2) applies to a party who is served with a changed notice of claim or reply under subrule (10.5) of this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Effect if defendant does not abandon part of a counterclaim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If this rule does not apply to a claim because the defendant has a counterclaim amounting to more than $10 000 and does not abandon part of the claim so that it may be heard under this rule, the claimant may sue for the whole amount to which the claimant may be entitled.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If this rule applies to a claim, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set the claim for trial under this rule, and
serve a notice of trial and blank trial statement (Form 33) on the parties to the claim at least 30 days before the date set for the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to change a trial date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may change a trial date

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by filing a consent to change the date under Rule 16 (1), or
by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: applying to the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)) for an order changing the date of the trial at least 7 days before the date set for the trial, unless the registrar orders otherwise, and
giving to the other party whatever notice of the application the registrar may order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Date may be changed to avoid unreasonable inconvenience
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may change the date of the trial on an application made under subrule (13) (b) if the registrar is satisfied that the original date is unreasonably inconvenient to the party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Unreasonably inconvenient
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of subrule (14), the registrar may determine that a date is unreasonably inconvenient to a party if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family emergency renders the party unable to attend on the day set for the trial,
the party has a pre-arranged out-of-town commitment on the day set for the trial and that commitment cannot be changed due to travel requirements,
the party is required to attend court on the day set for the trial, or
the registrar otherwise determines that the date is unreasonably inconvenient to the party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of change of date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the registrar changes the date of a trial under this rule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party who applied for the change of date must give to the other parties whatever notice of the change of date the registrar may order, and
the registrar must promptly set a new date for the trial and serve a notice of trial on the parties specifying the new date, time and place for the trial.

bcl:division.bcl:text: What the Parties Must Do Before the Trial

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the parties must file before the trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 14 days before the date set for the trial, each party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a trial statement (Form 33) following the instructions on the form, and
file at the registry the trial statement with attached copies of all relevant documents.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Serving the trial statement on other parties
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 7 days before the date set for the trial, each party must serve a copy of their trial statement and attachments on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not comply with subrule (17) or (18)
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party does not comply with subrule (17) or (18), an adjudicator may do one or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjourn the trial and order that party to pay all the reasonable expenses incurred by any other parties as a result of the adjournment;
order the trial to proceed without permitting that party to produce as evidence any information, document or records withheld as a result of the non-compliance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a trial may be conducted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The trial is to be conducted

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without complying with the formal rules of procedure and evidence, and

without limiting paragraph (a), in accordance with subrules (21) and (22) unless the adjudicator determines that there are reasons to conduct the trial with a formal examination and cross-examination of parties and witnesses.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Before a trial begins
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An adjudicator must do the following before the trial begins:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: review all documents filed by the parties;
determine whether the parties are able to settle the matter;
if the parties are able to settle the matter, make a payment order or other appropriate order in the terms agreed to by the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How the trial is conducted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the adjudicator determines that the parties are not able to settle the matter, the trial is to be conducted in accordance with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the beginning of the trial the adjudicator must have the parties take an oath or give an affirmation;
the adjudicator must ask the parties to state the facts related to the claim and file with the court any documents or other evidence on which the parties rely;
the adjudicator may allow a party to swear to the truth of the summary of facts set out in the party's filed trial statement;
the adjudicator must ask the parties to respond to each other;
the adjudicator may allow a party to call witnesses;

the adjudicator may receive evidence from an expert witness, or a witness with specialized knowledge, in the manner the adjudicator considers appropriate given the amount claimed and the complexity of the issues;
the adjudicator may allow a party or the party's lawyer or articling student to ask questions of another party or another party's witness;
the adjudicator may ask questions of the parties or other witnesses;
the adjudicator must allow a lawyer or articled student to make submissions for a party;
the adjudicator may receive evidence in any other way the adjudicator thinks is appropriate;
the adjudicator must review any relevant legislation and case law to which the parties refer;
the adjudicator may do one or more of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at any time adjourn the trial;
dismiss a claim, counterclaim or third party notice in whole or in part;
make a payment order or other appropriate order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Evidence to be sworn
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: All oral evidence must be given under oath or affirmation at the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Length of trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the adjudicator cannot conclude the hearing of the evidence within the period of time scheduled for the trial, the adjudicator may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: extend the trial beyond the time scheduled unless, in the adjudicator's opinion, extending the trial will unreasonably interfere with the next scheduled matter, or
adjourn the remainder of the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Orders respecting completion of adjourned trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the adjudicator adjourns the trial under subrule (24), the adjudicator may make any order with respect to the completion of the trial that the adjudicator thinks is appropriate.

bcl:division.bcl:text: If a Party Does Not Attend the Trial

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a defendant or third party does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant or third party does not attend the trial, either themselves or by a representative, the adjudicator may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: allow the claim, and
make a payment order or other appropriate order against that defendant or third party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claimant does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claimant does not attend the trial, either themselves or by a representative, the adjudicator may dismiss the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Adjudicator's decision after the trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The adjudicator must give a decision

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in court orally at the end of the trial or on a later date within 30 days after the end of the trial, or
in writing served on the parties within 30 days after the end of the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the oral decision is given later
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an adjudicator's decision is to be given orally on a later date, the registrar must notify the parties of the date.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When written decision effective
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An adjudicator's written decision is effective on the date it is filed at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application of other rules
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of applying Rules 8, 9, 11, 12, 16, 17 and 20 to a claim to which this rule applies, a reference in those Rules to a "judge" must be read as a reference to an "adjudicator".

bcl:rule.bcl:text:
Summary Trial for Financial Debt
(Pilot Project — Robson Square Small Claims Registry)

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claims to which this rule applies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule applies to a claim if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claim is made by way of a notice of claim, notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, counterclaim or third party notice and in respect of which

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a reply is filed opposing all or part of the claim, or
a response opposing all or part of the claim is continued as a reply,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one of the following applies in relation to the claim:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the claim is part of a proceeding started by a notice of claim and, after November 25, 2007,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the notice of claim was filed at the Robson Square Small Claims Registry (Vancouver), or
the court file relating to the claim was transferred to the Robson Square Small Claims Registry (Vancouver);

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the claim is part of a proceeding started by a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim and, on or after June 1, 2017,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim was filed at the Robson Square Small Claims Registry (Vancouver), or
the court file relating to the claim was transferred to the Robson Square Small Claims Registry (Vancouver),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the court file relating to the claim has not been transferred to another registry, and
the claimant is in the business of lending money or extending credit and the claim is for a debt that arises from a loan of money or the extension of credit in the course of that business.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If this rule applies to a claim, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set the claim for trial under this rule, and
serve a notice of trial on the parties to the claim at least 30 days before the date set for the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to change a trial date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may change a trial date

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by filing a consent to change the date under Rule 16 (1), or
by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: applying to the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)) for an order changing the date of the trial at least 7 days before the date set for the trial, unless the registrar orders otherwise, and
giving to the other party whatever notice of the application the registrar may order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Date may be changed to avoid unreasonable inconvenience
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may change the date of the trial on an application made under subrule (3) (b) if the registrar is satisfied that the original date is unreasonably inconvenient to the party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Unreasonably inconvenient
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of subrule (4), the registrar may determine that a date is unreasonably inconvenient to a party if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family emergency renders the party unable to attend on the day set for the trial,
the party has a pre-arranged out-of-town commitment on the day set for the trial and that commitment cannot be changed due to travel requirements,
the party is required to attend court on the day set for the trial, or
the registrar otherwise determines that the date is unreasonably inconvenient to the party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of change of date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the registrar changes the date of a trial under this rule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party who applied for the change of date must give to the other parties whatever notice of the change of date the registrar may order, and
the registrar must promptly set a new date for the trial and serve a notice of trial on the parties specifying the new date, time and place for the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the parties must file before the trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 14 days before the date set for the trial, each party must file at the registry any contracts, statements of account, proofs of payment or other documents on which the party intends to rely at the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the parties must serve on the other parties before trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 7 days before the date set for the trial, each party must serve a copy of the documents filed at the registry under subrule (7) on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How evidence will be heard at a trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may conduct a trial without complying with the formal rules of procedure and evidence, and in doing so may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ask the parties to explain their cases, to respond to each other and to call witnesses, or
receive evidence in any other way the judge thinks is appropriate.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Evidence to be sworn
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: All oral evidence must be given under oath or affirmation.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a defendant or third party does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant or third party does not attend the trial, either themselves or by a representative, the adjudicator may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: allow the claim, and
make a payment order or other appropriate order against that defendant or third party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claimant does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claimant does not attend the trial, either themselves or by a representative, the adjudicator may dismiss the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge's decision at the trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At the end of the trial, the judge must do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make a payment order;
dismiss the claim, counterclaim or third party notice;
if, in the judge's opinion, the claim cannot be decided at a trial under this rule,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: cancel the trial, and
order that the claim be set for

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a settlement conference under Rule 7,
a trial conference under Rule 7.5, or
a trial under Rule 9.1 or 10.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Additional orders made by judge
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge makes an order under subrule (13) (c), the judge may make any other order for the just, speedy and inexpensive resolution of the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claims to which this rule does not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule does not apply to a claim if Rule 9.1 or, subject to an order under Rule 9.2 (13) (c), Rule 9.2 applies to the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How evidence will be heard at a trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may conduct a trial without complying with the formal rules of procedure and evidence, and in doing so may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ask the parties to explain their cases, to respond to each other and to call witnesses (see Rules 7 (15) (b) and 7.5 (15) (b)), or
receive evidence in any other way the judge thinks is appropriate (see Rules 7 (15) (b) and 7.5 (15) (b)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Evidence to be sworn
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: All oral evidence must be given under oath or affirmation.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Experts' evidence — advance notice of evidence required
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may not call an expert to give evidence of the expert's opinion unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party serves a summary of the expert's evidence on all other parties at least 30 days before the expert is called to give evidence, or
a judge grants permission.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Experts' reports must be given in advance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Instead of calling an expert to give evidence, a party may introduce a report stating opinions of an expert, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party serves a copy of the report on all other parties at least 30 days before the report is introduced, or
a judge grants permission.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Experts' qualifications
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A statement of qualifications in an expert's report is proof that the expert has those qualifications unless there is evidence to the contrary.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Experts may be called for cross-examination
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party receiving another party's expert report may serve on the other party, at least 14 days before the trial date, a notice requiring the expert to attend the trial for cross-examination.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Cost of calling other party's expert
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge determines that calling another party's expert was unnecessary, the judge may order the party who required the expert to attend to pay the expert's expenses.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Estimates
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repair estimates and estimates of the value of property are not considered to be expert evidence, but must be served on all other parties at least 14 days before trial unless a judge orders otherwise.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a defendant does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant or third party does not attend the trial, either themselves or by a representative, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: allow the claim, and
make a payment order or other appropriate order against that defendant or third party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claimant does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claimant does not attend the trial, either themselves or by a representative, the judge may dismiss the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge's decision after the trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The judge must give a decision

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in court orally at the end of the trial or on a later date, or
in writing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the decision is given later
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge's decision is to be given orally on a later date, the registrar must notify the parties of the date.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When decision effective
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge's written decision is effective on the date it is filed at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claims to which this rule does not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule does not apply to a claim if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Rule 9.1 applies to the claim, or
the proceeding was started by a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Any party may offer to settle
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may offer to settle one or more claims by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: completing an offer to settle (Form 18), and
serving the party to whom the offer is made with the completed offer to settle as if it were a notice of claim (see Rule 2).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit for offering to settle
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An offer to settle under subrule (1) must be served on the party to whom the offer is made

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 30 days after the conclusion of the settlement conference or the conclusion of a trial conference, whichever happens first, or
at a later time, if permitted by a judge.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How an offer is accepted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party served with an offer to settle under subrule (2) wishes to accept the offer in full settlement of the claim, interest and expenses, that party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete an acceptance of offer (Form 19), and
within 28 days after being served with the offer, serve the party who made the offer with the completed acceptance as if it were a notice of claim (see Rule 2).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Acceptance of offer deemed to be a payment order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party served with an acceptance of offer files the offer and the acceptance in the registry, the acceptance is deemed to be a payment order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If an offer is rejected by claimant
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The trial judge may order a claimant to pay the defendant a penalty if the claimant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not accept an offer to settle made by the defendant under subrule (1), and
is awarded at trial an amount, including interest and all expenses, that equals or is less than the defendant's offer.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If an offer is rejected by defendant
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The trial judge may order a defendant to pay the claimant a penalty if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant does not accept an offer to settle made by the claimant under subrule (1), and
the claimant is awarded at trial an amount, including interest and all expenses, that equals or exceeds the claimant's offer.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Amount of penalty
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A penalty under subrule (5) or (6) is in addition to any other expenses or penalties, and may be up to 20% of the amount of the offer to settle.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the judge must consider
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: When deciding the amount of a penalty under subrule (5) or (6), a judge must consider

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the difference between the amount awarded at trial and the amount of the offer to settle,
the interest of the parties in proceeding to trial to determine the credibility of witnesses or a point of law, and
the time when the offer was made.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Other offers to settle
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An offer to settle may be made and accepted after the time limit in this Rule for offering or accepting a settlement has passed, but in that case a judge may not impose a penalty under subrule (5) or (6).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Money paid into court after garnishing order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant may include in an offer to settle a term that money paid into court as a result of a garnishing order be paid to the claimant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Disclosure to judge
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may disclose any offer to settle made under this Rule

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to the settlement conference judge, and
to the trial judge, but only after that judge has given a final decision on the amount to be awarded.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Multiple defendants
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If 2 or more defendants are sued together,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a claimant may not make an offer to settle except jointly to all defendants, and
a defendant may not make an offer to settle except jointly with all other defendants.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Multiple claimants
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there are 2 or more claimants, a separate offer to settle may be made by or to each of them.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Counterclaims and third party claims
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule applies to claims, counterclaims and third party claims.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Third party claims
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant accepts an offer to settle made by a third party,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the third party must pay the amount of the offer into court, and
that amount may only be taken out of court by order of a judge or with the consent of all parties.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Penalties if Final Decision by Civil Resolution Tribunal

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claims to which this rule applies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule applies to claims, counterclaims and third party claims if the proceeding was started by a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claims to which this rule does not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule does not apply to a claim if a claimant and a defendant filed a notice of objection under section 56.1 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act in respect of the claim when the claim was proceeding as a tribunal small claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Multiple claims
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there are 2 or more claims in a proceeding, this rule is to be applied separately in respect of each claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If claimant is awarded an equal or lesser amount at trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The trial judge may order a claimant to pay the defendant a penalty if the claimant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filed a notice of objection under section 56.1 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act in respect of the claim when the claim was proceeding as a tribunal small claim, and
is awarded at trial an amount, including interest and all expenses, that equals or is less than the amount awarded by the civil resolution tribunal against the defendant in respect of that claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If claimant is awarded an equal or greater amount at trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The trial judge may order a defendant to pay the claimant a penalty if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant filed a notice of objection under section 56.1 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act in respect of the claim when the claim was proceeding as a tribunal small claim, and

the claimant is awarded at trial an amount, including interest and all expenses, that equals or exceeds the amount awarded by the civil resolution tribunal against the defendant in respect of that claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Amount of penalty
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A penalty under subrule (4) or (5) is in addition to any other expenses or penalties, and may be up to 20% of the amount awarded by the civil resolution tribunal.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the judge must consider
