bcl:subrule.bcl:text: When deciding the amount of a penalty under subrule (4) or (5), a judge must consider the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the difference between the amount awarded at trial and the amount awarded by the civil resolution tribunal;
the interest of the parties in proceeding to trial to determine the credibility of witnesses or a point of law;
whether the civil resolution tribunal made a final decision after a party did not attend or otherwise participate in a civil resolution tribunal hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Payment order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge decides that one party must pay money to another party, the judge must make a payment order at the end of the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Payment deferral
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After making a payment order, the judge must ask

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the debtor requires time to pay, and
if so, when the debtor proposes to pay.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Creditor to be consulted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the debtor asks for time to pay, the judge must ask the creditor if the creditor agrees with the debtor's proposal.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the creditor agrees
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the creditor agrees with the proposal, the judge may order a payment schedule requiring the debt to be paid by a set date or by instalments.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the creditor does not agree
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the creditor does not agree with the proposal, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order a payment hearing, or
order a payment schedule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: No collection while payments being made
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The creditor may not take any other steps to collect the debt as long as the debtor is making payments in accordance with the payment schedule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If no order is made
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If no order is made under subrule (5), the debt is payable immediately and the creditor may collect the debt by taking any of the steps listed in subrule (11).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a judge orders a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge orders a payment hearing under subrule (5), the creditor may not take any other steps to collect payment until after the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar's payment order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may make a payment order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar may make some orders without a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may make the following orders without a hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a payment order in the amount agreed to plus expenses under Rule 20 (2) (a) and (b) and any interest the claimant is entitled to if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the defendant agrees to pay all or part of a claim on a reply, and
the claimant consents;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order establishing a payment schedule if the defendant proposes or requests a payment schedule in the reply and the claimant consents to the order;
an order issuing a summons to a defendant to attend a payment hearing if a proposed payment schedule is not agreed to by the claimant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How payment may be collected
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To collect payment due under a payment order (Form 10), a creditor may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ask the registrar to issue an order for seizure and sale under subrule (12);
ask for a payment hearing under Rule 12 (3);
ask a judge or registrar to issue a garnishing order under the Court Order Enforcement Act;
ask for a default hearing under Rule 13 (2), if the debtor defaults in making payments under a payment schedule;
enforce the order by any other means permitted by law.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Address for service form
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A creditor who wishes to collect payment under subrule (11) and has not yet filed an address for service (Form 38) must, in addition to doing anything set out in subrule (11), file an address for service and serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When an order for seizure and sale may be issued
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may issue an order for seizure and sale (Form 11) if a creditor

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: completes the form, following the instructions on the form, and
files it at the registry, together with a copy of the relevant decision, certificate or order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How long an order for seizure and sale is in effect
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an order for seizure and sale has not been enforced within 12 months after it was issued, it expires but the creditor may ask the registrar to issue another one.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a debtor does not obey a payment schedule
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a debtor defaults on the payments under a payment schedule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the balance of the money required to be paid under the payment order becomes due immediately, and
the creditor may collect the entire amount by taking any of the steps listed in subrule (11).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a decision is reserved
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a payment order is made in the absence of the parties because the judge reserved the decision,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the creditor may take any of the steps listed in subrule (11), and
the debtor may ask for a payment hearing under Rule 12 (10).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a payment order is made in favour of a young person
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a payment order is made in favour of a person under 19 years of age, a judge may order the amount payable under the order to be paid to the Public Guardian and Trustee for that person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Collection while payment hearing outstanding
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a summons to a payment hearing has been filed, the creditor may not take any other steps to collect payment until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the payment hearing has concluded, or
the summons has been withdrawn or cancelled.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Collection after warrant for arrest ordered
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a warrant is issued for the arrest of a debtor or of an officer, director or employee of a corporate debtor, the creditor may take any steps to collect payment due under a payment order as if a payment hearing had concluded.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Purpose of a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The purpose of a payment hearing is to allow a judge or justice to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assess the debtor's ability to pay, and
consider whether a payment schedule should be ordered.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Parties may request a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A payment hearing will be held if it is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: requested by the creditor under subrule (3),
requested by the debtor under subrule (10), or
ordered by the judge under Rule 11 (5) (a).

bcl:division.bcl:text: If a Creditor Asks for a Payment Hearing

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a creditor asks for a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To ask for a payment hearing, a creditor must complete a summons to a payment hearing (Form 12), following the instructions on the form, and file it at the registry at least 14 days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a creditor is not allowed to ask for a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A creditor who has an order for seizure and sale outstanding against the debtor may not ask for a payment hearing without the permission of a judge (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the debtor is a corporation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the debtor is a corporation, an officer, director or employee of the corporation may be summoned to the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the debtor is a partnership
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the debtor is a partnership, a partner may be summoned to the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of the summons
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person named in a summons to a payment hearing must be served by leaving the summons, together with the following documents, with the person at least 14 days before the date of the payment hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a blank supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39);
a blank statement of finances (Form 40), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Summons may be cancelled if wrong person summoned
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a summons to a payment hearing may apply to a judge (see Rule 16 (7)) who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cancel the summons if the person is not the right person to provide information on behalf of the debtor, and
direct the registrar to issue a new summons to someone who is the right person to provide the information.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person summoned by a creditor must file
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person summoned by a creditor to a payment hearing must file the following records and other things at least 7 days before the date of the payment hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), unless the person is not required to file any other records or other things under this subrule;
a statement of finances (Form 40), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership;
any other records or other things required by the summons;
any other records or other things on which the person intends to rely at the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person summoned by a creditor must serve
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person summoned by a creditor to a payment hearing must serve on the creditor the records and other things filed under subrule (9) (b), (c) or (d) at least 2 business days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor must update statement of finances if necessary
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there is a significant change to the debtor's finances after filing a statement of finances and before the payment hearing, the debtor must, before the start of the payment hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a revised statement of finances (Form 40), with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
serve the revised statement of finances on the creditor.

bcl:division.bcl:text: If a Debtor Asks for a Payment Hearing

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a debtor asks for a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To ask for a payment hearing, a debtor must complete the following forms, following the instructions on the forms, and file them at the registry at least 14 days before the date of the payment hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of payment hearing (Form 13);
a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership;
a statement of finances (Form 40), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Address for service form
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A debtor who wishes to ask for a payment hearing and has not yet filed an address for service (Form 38) must file an address for service and serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of notice on creditor
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The debtor must serve on the creditor the notice and the statement of finances, if applicable, at least 14 days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a debtor must file if the debtor asks for a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A debtor must file any records or other things on which the debtor intends to rely at the payment hearing and that were not filed under subrule (10), together with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), at least 7 days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a debtor must serve if the debtor asks for a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A debtor must serve on the creditor any records or other things filed under subrule (11.1) at least 2 business days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor must update statement of finances if necessary
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there is a significant change to the debtor's finances after filing a statement of finances and before the payment hearing, the debtor must, before the start of the payment hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a revised statement of finances (Form 40), with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
serve the revised statement of finances on the creditor.

bcl:division.bcl:text: If a Judge Orders a Payment Hearing

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person must file if a judge orders a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person ordered by a judge under Rule 11 (5) (a) to attend a payment hearing must file the following records and other things at least 7 days before the date of the payment hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), unless the person is not required to file any other records or other things under this subrule;
a statement of finances (Form 40), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership;
any other records or other things required by the order;
any other records or other things on which the person intends to rely at the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person must serve if a judge orders a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person ordered by a judge under Rule 11 (5) (a) to attend a payment hearing must serve on the creditor the records and other things filed under subrule (11.4) (b), (c) or (d) at least 2 business days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor must update statement of finances if necessary
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there is a significant change to the debtor's finances after filing a statement of finances and before the payment hearing, the debtor must, before the start of the payment hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a revised statement of finances (Form 40), with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
serve the revised statement of finances on the creditor.

bcl:division.bcl:text: What Happens at a Payment Hearing

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What happens at a payment hearing?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At any payment hearing under these rules, evidence may be heard about any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the income and assets of the debtor;
the debts owed to and by the debtor;
any assets that the debtor has disposed of since the claim arose;
the means that the debtor has, or may have in the future, of paying the amount owed.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: A payment schedule may be ordered
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After hearing the evidence and submissions by the parties, the judge or justice may order a payment schedule specifying

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date by which the debt must be paid, or
the amounts and dates of the instalments.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a creditor does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a creditor does not attend a payment hearing, the judge or justice may hold the hearing, cancel it or postpone it.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a person summoned or ordered to attend does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a creditor asks, a judge or justice may issue a warrant (Form 9) for the arrest of a person who does not attend a payment hearing and who was

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: served with a summons to attend, or
present before a judge or justice when the judge or justice ordered the person to attend.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor may swear or affirm — statement of finances
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a debtor has filed a statement of finances (Form 40), the judge or justice may direct the debtor to swear or affirm to the truth of the contents of the statement of finances at the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a creditor may ask for a default hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A creditor may ask the registrar for a default hearing if the debtor does not obey a payment schedule that was

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: made in an order under Rule 7 (14) (c) (at a settlement conference),
made in an order under Rule 7.5 (14) (b) (at a trial conference),
made under Rule 11 (4) (at the trial),
made under Rule 12 (13) (at a payment hearing), or
changed under Rule 17 (3).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a creditor asks for a default hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To ask for a default hearing, the creditor must complete a summons (Form 14), following the instructions on the form, and file it at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the debtor is a corporation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the debtor is a corporation, an officer, director or employee of the corporation may be summoned to the default hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the debtor is a partnership
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the debtor is a partnership, a partner may be summoned to the default hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of the summons
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person named in a summons to a default hearing must be served by a court bailiff or sheriff leaving the summons with the person at least 14 days before the date of the default hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What must be served with the summons
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The court bailiff or sheriff who serves a person under subrule (5) must also provide the person with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a blank supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
a blank statement of finances (Form 40), unless the person being served is a corporation or a partnership.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person who is served with a summons must file
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a summons to a default hearing must file the following records and other things at the registry at least 7 days before the date of the default hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), unless the person is not required to file any other records or other things under this subrule;
a statement of finances (Form 40), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership;
any other records or other things required by the summons;
any other records or other things on which the person intends to rely at the default hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person who is served with a summons must serve
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a summons to a default hearing must serve on the creditor the records and other things filed under subrule (6) (b), (c) or (d) at least 2 business days before the date of the default hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor must update statement of finances if necessary
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there is a significant change to the debtor's finances after filing a statement of finances and before the default hearing, the debtor must, before the start of the default hearing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a revised statement of finances (Form 40), with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
serve the revised statement of finances on the creditor.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the judge may do at a default hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At a default hearing, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: confirm the terms of a payment schedule or other order, or
change the terms of a payment schedule or other order in any manner that the judge thinks is fair to the debtor and the creditor.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may order debtor imprisoned
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The judge may issue a warrant (Form 15) requiring the debtor to be imprisoned for a specified period of not more than 20 days if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the debtor has not obeyed a payment schedule, and
the debtor's explanation, or failure to give an explanation, of why the payment schedule has not been obeyed is considered by the judge to amount to contempt of court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a person does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the creditor asks, the judge may issue a warrant (Form 9) for the arrest of a person who does not attend a default hearing and who was

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: served with a summons to attend, or
present before a judge when the judge ordered the person to attend.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor may swear or affirm — statement of finances
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a debtor has filed a statement of finances (Form 40), the judge may direct the debtor to swear or affirm to the truth of the contents of the statement of finances at the default hearing.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Warrant of Arrest for Not Attending Court

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of arrest
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a warrant of arrest is issued under Rule 9 (7), 12 (15) or 13 (9), the registrar must serve the person named in the warrant with a notice of arrest.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person may do after receiving a notice of arrest
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a notice of arrest may contact the registrar to arrange to attend court voluntarily.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Sheriff or peace officer may arrest
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person who is served with a notice of arrest does not arrange, within 7 days after the date of service, to attend court voluntarily, a sheriff or peace officer may arrest the person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Sheriff or peace officer must bring arrested person to court
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A sheriff or peace officer who arrests a person under subrule (3) must promptly bring the person to court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a judge or justice may do
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person attends court voluntarily under subrule (2) or under arrest under subrule (3), the judge or justice may release the person and may order the person to attend on another date.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of warrant
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person named in a warrant attends court voluntarily under subrule (5), the warrant is cancelled.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a person fails to appear as ordered
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person has been ordered under subrule (5) to appear on another date and the person does not appear as ordered, a judge may issue a warrant (Form 9) for the immediate arrest of the person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How long the warrant is in effect
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A warrant of arrest remains in force for 12 months from the date of its issue, but at the end of that period it expires and no one may be arrested under it.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: If a Warrant of Imprisonment Is Issued

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Imprisonment
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a warrant of imprisonment is issued under Rule 13 (8) or 19 (1), a sheriff or peace officer may arrest the person named in the warrant and deliver that person to the director of a correctional centre referred to in the warrant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How long the warrant is in effect
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A warrant of imprisonment remains in force for 12 months from the date of its issue, but at the end of that period it expires and no one may be imprisoned under it.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor may pay
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a warrant of imprisonment is issued under Rule 13 (8), the debtor may pay the amount stated in the warrant to the registrar or to a sheriff, peace officer or warden who has custody of the person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the registrar does after receiving payment
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the money is paid to the registrar, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a receipt for the payment and then pay that amount to the creditor, and
if the debtor has not yet been arrested, cancel the warrant of imprisonment.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Release after payment
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A sheriff, peace officer or warden must release a debtor imprisoned under a warrant of imprisonment if the debtor

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pays the amount stated in the warrant, or
shows a registrar's receipt for payment of the amount.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Money to be given to the creditor
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A sheriff, peace officer or warden who receives money under this rule must forward the money to the registrar for payment to the creditor named in the warrant of imprisonment.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Imprisonment does not cancel the debt
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Imprisonment under these rules does not cancel the debt or any right of the creditor to take steps to collect it.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Consent orders
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (1.1), a registrar may make an order that all parties to a claim consent to if one of them

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: files an application that contains the particulars of the order requested, and
satisfies the registrar that their consent was given.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: No consent orders to change method of attendance for a trial, payment hearing or default hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An order to change a person's method of attendance for a trial, payment hearing or default hearing cannot be made under subrule (1).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Some applications may be granted without a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A registrar may make any of the following orders without a hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order renewing a claim or a third party notice (see Rules 2 (7) and 5 (5.1));
an order renewing a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim (see Rule 1.1 (17));
an order changing the date of the settlement conference (see Rule 7 (7));
an order changing the date of a mediation session (see Rule 7.3 (30));
an order changing the date of a trial conference (see Rule 7.5 (5) or (6));
an order extending the time for filing a certificate of readiness (see Rule 1.1 (49) or 7 (10));
an order extending the time for filing a certificate of compliance (see Rule 1.1 (45);
an order changing the applicant's method of attendance at a conference or hearing, other than a trial, payment hearing or default hearing (see Rule 17 (16.1) (a));
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 244/2015, Sch. 3, s. 7 (c).]
an order authorizing a person to attend a mediation session by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication (see Rule 7.3 (25));
an order changing the date of a trial (see Rule 9.1 (14) or 9.2 (4));
an order permitting service of a notice of claim outside British Columbia (see Rule 18 (6));
an order permitting a claimant to serve a notice of claim or a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim by another method of service (see Rule 18 (8) (a) or (8.1) (a));
an order exempting someone from paying fees (see Rule 20 (1));
any other order that the registrar is authorized to make without notice to another party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a registrar orders a different method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a registrar makes an order under subrule (2) (c.1), the registrar must direct the applicant where or how to attend, including by providing a telephone number or video conference information, if applicable.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply to a registrar
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order listed in subrule (2), a person must complete an application (Form 16), following the instructions on the form, and file it at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Applicant must file and serve address for service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an applicant has not yet filed an address for service (Form 38), the applicant must also file an address for service and serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar may prepare the order or refer it to a judge
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may prepare, sign and record an order under subrule (1) or (2) or Rule 11 (10) or may refer the application to a judge.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the judge may do
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the application is referred to a judge, the judge may make the order or direct the applicant to appear before a judge to explain why the order should be made.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Some applications require a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may make any of the following orders after a hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order changing the date of a trial (see Rule 4 (7) or 9 (6));
an order permitting a third party claim to be made (see Rule 5 (1));
a default order if no reply to a counterclaim or third party notice is filed (see Rule 6 (2)) or if an application is made under Rule 7.3 (40);
an order transferring a claim to the Supreme Court (see Rule 7.1 (1) (a) and (2));
an order extending the time for serving an offer to settle (see Rule 10.1 (1) (b));
an order permitting a late reply to be filed (see Rule 6 (8));
an order for a medical examination (see Rule 7 (12) or 7.5 (13.1));
an order setting a place for a trial (see Rule 7 (19));
an order exempting a disputed claim from the application of Rule 7.3 (see Rule 7.3 (29));
a mediation compensation order (see Rule 7.3 (50) (b));
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 244/2015, Sch. 3, s. 8 (b).]
an order cancelling or varying a summons to witness (see Rule 9 (5));
an order permitting a creditor to ask for a payment hearing (see Rule 12 (4));
an order changing or cancelling an order made in the absence of a party (see Rule 17 (1));

an order cancelling a default order or dismissal order (see Rule 17 (2)), and if the application is granted the judge may order payment of any reasonable expenses of the other party related to the cancellation;
an order changing or cancelling the terms of a payment schedule (see Rule 17 (3));
an order postponing or adjourning a trial (see Rule 17 (5.1);
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 161/2022, s. 58 (b).]
an order for failing to obey a rule (see Rule 17 (13));
a review of a decision of a registrar (see Rule 17 (22));
an order that a person make a deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act (see Rule 1.1 (40) or (41));
an order dismissing a claim if no deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act is made by a claimant (see Rule 1.1 (41.10));

a default order if no deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act is made by a defendant under a counterclaim or under a third party notice or by a third party (see Rule 1.1 (41.12));
any other order that a judge has the power to make and notice of which is served on another party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Orders that do not require a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The following orders may be made without a hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order changing a person's method of attendance at any of the following hearings (see Rule 17 (16.1) (b) and (c)):

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: trial;
payment hearing;
default hearing;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order changing the method of attendance at a conference or hearing, other than a trial, payment hearing or default hearing, (see Rule 17 (16.1) (c)) for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a person other than the applicant, or
the applicant and a person other than the applicant;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order extending or shortening a time limit (see Rule 17 (12));
an order correcting an accidental slip or omission in an order (see Rule 17 (14));
any other order that a judge has the power to make and for which notice to another party is not required.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge or justice may require a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrule (6.1), a judge or justice may direct an applicant to appear before a judge or justice to explain why the order should be made.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of application and method of attendance if hearing is required
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge or justice directs an applicant to appear at a hearing under subrule (6.2), the judge or justice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may direct the applicant to serve the application under subrule (7.2) on a party or an affected person, and
may, without a hearing, make an order respecting a person's method of attendance at the hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply to a judge
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order listed in subrule (6), other than subrule (6) (n.1), a person must complete an application (Form 17), following the instructions on the form, and file it at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply to a judge — subrule (6) (n.1)
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order under subrule (6) (n.1), a party must complete an application for deposit (Form 35), following the instructions on the form, and file it at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply to a judge or justice for an order without a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order under subrule (6.1), a person must complete an application (Form 17), following the instructions on the form, and file it at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Cost of method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge or justice makes an order under subrule (6.1) (a) or (b), the judge or justice may order that the party requesting to change the person's method of attendance must pay for the telephone call, video conference or other reasonable cost of that person's method of attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge or justice must direct where or how to attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge or justice makes an order under subrule (6.1) (a) or (b) or (6.3) (b), the judge or justice must direct the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: how, and by what date, to submit and serve any records and other things, if the party or witness will not be attending in person, and
where or how to attend, including by providing a telephone number or video conferencing information, if applicable.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When registrar must send amended notice
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge or justice changes the method of attendance for a hearing or conference for all parties, the registrar must notify the parties of the new method of attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application may be filed at another registry
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A registrar may allow an application under subrule (7), (7.1) or (7.2) to be filed at a registry other than the registry where the court file is if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all the parties agree, or
the registrar is satisfied that the application is urgent.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Applicant must serve notice
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 7 days before the date set for hearing an application under subrule (7) or (7.1), the applicant must serve a copy of the application, and the affidavit if required (see Rule 17 (2)), on each party that would be affected by the order requested unless the application is for a default order because no reply to a third party notice has been filed.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Documents to support an application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who applies for an order that requires a hearing must file all documents on which the person intends to rely at the hearing, with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), at the registry at least 7 days before the date set for the hearing unless the registrar allows the application to be made as an urgent application under subrule (10).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Final decision of the civil resolution tribunal must not be filed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrule (9.1), a person must not file at the registry a final decision of the civil resolution tribunal in relation to the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of documents to support an application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person must serve all documents filed under subrule (9.1) on each party that would be affected by the order requested, and on each affected person who must be served under subrule (6.3) (a), at least 7 days before the date set for the hearing, unless the registrar allows the application to be made as an urgent application under subrule (10).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to respond to an application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party or affected person is served with a notice of application and wishes to respond, the party or affected person must attend the hearing of the application.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Documents to support a response
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party or affected person responding to an application intends to rely on documents at the hearing, at least two business days before the date set for the hearing, the party or affected person must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file at the registry any documents on which the person intends to rely at the hearing, with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
serve the documents on each party that would be affected by the order requested and on each affected person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service not required in urgent cases
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If satisfied that an application is urgent, a registrar may allow an application to be made under subrule (6) even though the other parties have not been served.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Where the application will be heard
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application under subrule (7) or (7.1) will be heard at the court served by the registry where the court file is, except that the registrar may allow it to be heard at another location of the court if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all the parties agree, or
the registrar is satisfied that the application is urgent.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Applicant must serve order on other parties
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: As soon as practicable after an order is made under this Rule and unless a judge, justice or registrar otherwise orders, the person who applied for the order must serve a copy of the order on

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all parties who did not attend the hearing of the application or did not receive notice of the application, and
if the application was about a witness and if the witness did not receive notice of the application, the witness.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Application for Exemption from Adjudication of Claim by Civil Resolution Tribunal

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for an order that civil resolution tribunal not adjudicate claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order, under section 16.2 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act, that the civil resolution tribunal not adjudicate a tribunal small claim or a tribunal accident claim, a party must complete an application for exemption (Form 36) following the instructions on the form.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing an application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The applicant must file the application for exemption and pay the required fee at the Small Claims Registry nearest to where

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person against whom the tribunal small claim or the tribunal accident claim is made lives or carries on business, or
the transaction or event that resulted in the matter brought before the civil resolution tribunal took place.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit for filing application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The application for exemption must be filed within 14 days after the date that a response under section 7 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act in respect of the tribunal small claim or the tribunal accident claim was received or made by the applicant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Documents to be filed with the application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The applicant must file with the application for exemption the following documents in respect of all tribunal small claims or tribunal accident claims that were to be resolved in a single proceeding before the civil resolution tribunal:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all initiating notices received by the applicant;
all responses under section 7 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act received or made by the applicant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Applicant must serve notice
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 7 days before the date set for hearing an application under subrule (1), the applicant must serve a copy of the application on each party that would be affected by the order requested.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service not required in urgent cases
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If satisfied that an application is urgent, a registrar may allow an application to be made under subrule (5) even though the other parties have not been served.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 191/2021, s. 35.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote:
Changing or cancelling orders made in the absence of a party
other than dismissal orders or default orders
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may change or cancel an order made in the absence of a party other than dismissal orders or default orders if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that party applies (see Rule 16 (7)) within a reasonable time, and
there is a good reason for changing or cancelling the order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Cancelling dismissal order or default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may cancel a dismissal order or default order if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the order was made

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the absence of a party,
for failing to file a reply, or
for failing to make a deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party applies (see Rule 16 (7)) and attaches to the application an affidavit containing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the reason the party did not file a reply, attend the settlement conference, trial conference or trial or make a deposit under section 56.3 of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act,
the reason for any delay if there has been delay in filing the application, and
the facts that support the claim or the defence.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Terms of payment schedule may be changed or cancelled
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The creditor or the debtor may apply to a judge (see Rule 16 (7)) to change or cancel the terms of payment in a payment schedule and the judge may make any order that the judge thinks is fair.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may make orders subject to conditions
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In making an order under these rules, a judge may impose any condition or give any direction that the judge thinks is fair.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may cancel, postpone or adjourn conferences or hearings
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may cancel, postpone or adjourn a conference or hearing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a specified date,
to a date to be set by the registrar, or
without setting a date.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Postponement or adjournment of a trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A trial may only be postponed or adjourned

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under subrule (5), Rule 4 (7), Rule 7.5 (15), Rule 9 (6), Rule 9.1 (19), (22) (l) (i) or (24) or Rule 17 (16.3), or
if a party applies to a judge under Rule 16 (7) and the judge is satisfied that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the postponement or adjournment is unavoidable, and
an injustice will result to one of the parties if the trial proceeds.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Fee to postpone or adjourn a trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party who is notified of a trial date 45 or more days before the trial date and who applies under subrule (5.1) (b) or Rule 4 (7) to postpone or adjourn the trial must, if the postponement or adjournment is granted, pay the fee for resetting a trial unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application is made 30 or more days before the trial date, or
the claim is settled within the applicable period as described in subrule (5.3).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Time to pay fee to postpone or adjourn a trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The fee required by subrule (5.2) must be paid within

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the period of 14 days after the granting of the postponement or adjournment, or
a longer period set by the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Failure to pay fee to postpone or adjourn a trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party fails to pay the fee required by subrule (5.2), a judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: dismiss the claim if that party is the claimant,
strike out the reply, counterclaim or third party notice and make a payment order if that party is a defendant, or
make any other order the judge thinks is fair.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Where in-person appearances take place
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: All steps in a proceeding that are to be attended in person will take place at the court location where the proceeding was started, except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a judge orders otherwise, or
as provided in Rule 16 (11) and Rule 17 (8).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may change place of a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may direct that a hearing that is set for one place be held at another place.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Chief judge may change place of conferences and hearings
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The chief judge may order that any and all conferences and hearings set at one place be heard at another place.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Creditor may enforce order at another place
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The creditor may take steps to enforce a default order or a payment order at a registry other than where the court file is if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that registry is nearest to where the debtor lives or carries on business, and
the creditor files at that registry a certified true copy of the order and an affidavit stating the amount still owing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When orders take effect
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An order takes effect on the day it was made unless otherwise ordered by the judge or registrar who made the order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: First and last days are not counted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In calculating time under these rules or an order, the number of days between 2 events is counted by excluding the days on which those events happen.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the last day is a holiday
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the last day of a period of time for filing or serving a document or doing any other thing under these rules or an order falls on a day when the registry is closed, the time ends on the next day that the registry is open.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may extend or shorten times
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At any time, including after a time limit has expired, a judge may extend or shorten a time limit set by these rules or by any order of the court, on the terms that the judge thinks are fair.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not obey the rules
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party who thinks that another party has not obeyed these rules may apply to a judge under Rule 16 (7) or at a hearing, and the judge may make any order or give any direction that the judge thinks is fair.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Correction of orders
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may correct an accidental slip or omission in an order and may add provisions on expenses, interest or anything else that was not but should have been adjudicated on.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge has registrar's powers
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may exercise any power or perform any duty given to a registrar by these rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 161/2022, s. 71.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to change method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrules (25) and (26), a person may apply to change their own or another person's method of attendance at a conference or hearing as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a registrar under Rule 16 (1) or (3) to change the applicant's own method of attendance at a conference or hearing, other than a trial, payment hearing or default hearing;
to a judge or justice under Rule 16 (7.2) to change the applicant's own method of attendance at a payment hearing;
to a judge under Rule 16 (7.2)

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to change a person's method of attendance at a trial or default hearing, or
to change the method of attendance at a conference or hearing for

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a person other than the applicant, or
the applicant and a person other than the applicant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 161/2022, s. 71.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Participants may be required to appear in person
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A registrar, justice or judge who is conducting a conference or hearing at which participants are appearing by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication may adjourn the conference or hearing at any time and require participants to attend in person or in another manner that the registrar, justice or judge considers appropriate in the circumstances.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Faxed documents
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A registrar may accept for filing any document, except a notice of claim, notice of civil resolution tribunal claim or a reply, that has been transmitted to the registry by a fax machine.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Supreme Court Civil Rules
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Only the following Supreme Court Civil Rules apply to proceedings under the Small Claims Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Rule 10-1 [Detention, Preservation and Recovery of Property];
Rule 10-3 [Interpleader];
Rule 13-2 (4) (only as to writs of delivery) and (7) [Enforcement of Orders];
Rule 20-2 [Persons Under Disability], except Rule 20-2 (4);
Rule 20-2 (4) (only as to personal injury cases).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Settlements involving young persons
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person (litigation guardian) who makes a claim for personal injury on behalf of someone under 19 years of age must act by a solicitor and may not settle the claim without the consent of the Public Guardian and Trustee.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How the parties may be represented
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Any party who wishes to be represented in court may be represented by a lawyer or an articled student, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the party is a corporation, by a director, officer or authorized employee,
if the party is a partnership, by a partner or an authorized employee, or
if the party is using a business name, by the owner of the business or any authorized employee.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Party may appeal the registrar's decision
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party is dissatisfied with a decision of a registrar, the party may apply (see Rule 16 (7)) to a judge for a review of the registrar's decision.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the judge may do
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After hearing those parties who attend, the judge may confirm or change the registrar's decision.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Physical presence not required
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of these Rules, a reference to accompanying, attending, appearing, conducting, giving, being before a judge, being in court or being at a place or location is not to be interpreted as requiring in-person attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Hearing or conference has an associated physical location
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a hearing or conference does not take place at a physical location because all participants attend the hearing or conference by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication, the hearing or conference is considered to take place at the court served by the registry where the court file is.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Default method of attendance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Conferences and hearings must be attended in person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Direction of chief judge
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrule (25), the chief judge may direct that a class of conferences or hearings, other than hearings under Rule 9.1 [Simplified Trials for Claims up to $10 000], 9.2 [Summary Trial for Financial Debt], 10 [The Trial] or 13 [Default Hearing], must be attended by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Classes of conferences or hearings
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A direction under subrule (26) may be different for different court locations, court registries, types of court appearances, classes of persons or circumstances.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Procedures in Fax Filing Pilot Project Registries

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Definition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: clerk means a member of the registry staff;

fax filing pilot project registry means the Chilliwack, Cranbrook, Dawson Creek, Kamloops, Kelowna, Nelson, Penticton, Prince George, Rossland, Salmon Arm, Smithers, Terrace, Vernon or Williams Lake Small Claims registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application of this rule
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite rule 17 (17) and subject to this rule, if a registry is a fax filing pilot project registry, a registrar or clerk may accept any document in a filing that has been transmitted to the registry by fax, except the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a certificate of service respecting an application for a default order;
a certificate of judgment under section 88 of the Court Order Enforcement Act;
an order under section 76 of the Offence Act;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 267/2018, s. 14.]
a decision or order of the director under section 85 of the Residential Tenancy Act;
a decision or order of the director under section 78 of the Manufactured Home Park Tenancy Act;
a restitution order under section 741 of the Criminal Code.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a fax filing may be refused
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A registrar or clerk may refuse to accept a filing that is transmitted to a fax filing pilot project registry by fax for any one or more of the following reasons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the filing is not accompanied by a fax cover sheet in Form 20;
the filing relates to more than one claim;
the filing and the fax cover sheet exceed 20 pages in length and the registrar has not given leave;
applicable registry services fees have not been paid;
in the opinion of the registrar or clerk, the filing is illegible and cannot be used by the court;
the filing is incomplete;
the filing should have been transmitted to another fax filing pilot project registry;
the filing does not otherwise conform to practice and procedure under these rules and any applicable enactment.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a fax filing is filed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A filing that is transmitted to a fax filing pilot project registry by fax and received by the registry fax machine will be filed as soon as is practicable, provided that it has not been refused under subrule (3).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a fax filing is considered to be filed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A filing that is transmitted to a fax filing pilot project registry by fax is considered to be filed on the date stamped on it by a clerk.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Original of fax filing may be required by judge
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may require that the original of a document transmitted to a fax filing pilot project registry by fax in accordance with this rule be produced.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Other Rules about Service and Proving Service

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve a notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim on a municipality
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant is a municipal corporation, regional district or other local government body, the notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim must be served by giving a copy to the clerk, deputy clerk or some similar official.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve a notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim on a young person
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant is under 19 years of age, the notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim must be served by leaving a copy of the notice with the defendant's parent or guardian unless a judge orders otherwise.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve a society
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant is a society within the meaning of the Societies Act, the notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim must be served

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by mailing a copy of it by registered mail to the mailing address of the society's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies, or
by leaving a copy of it

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at the delivery address of the society's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies, or
with a director, officer, receiver manager or liquidator of the society.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve an extraprovincial non-share corporation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant is an extraprovincial non-share corporation within the meaning of the Societies Act, the notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim must be served

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with section 176 of that Act,

by mailing a copy of it by registered mail to the mailing address for an attorney, referred to in section 170 of that Act, of the extraprovincial non-share corporation on file with the Registrar of Companies, or
if neither paragraph (a) nor (b) of this subrule applies, by following subrule (3) (b) (ii).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve an unincorporated association and trade union
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the defendant is an unincorporated association, including a trade union, the notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim must be served

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by mailing a copy of it by registered mail to the registered office of the association, or
by leaving a copy of it with an officer of the association, or in the case of a trade union, with a business agent.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of a notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim outside British Columbia
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim may be served on a person outside British Columbia if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an individual who normally resides in British Columbia, or
a corporation that has assets in British Columbia but is incorporated outside British Columbia and is not an extraprovincial company,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the transaction or event that resulted in the claim took place in British Columbia, or
the registrar gives permission (see Rule 16 (3)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve a corporation outside British Columbia
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim authorized under subrule (6) to be served on a corporation outside British Columbia must be served

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by mailing a copy of it by registered mail to a place of business or registered office of the corporation outside British Columbia, or
by leaving a copy of it

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at a place of business or registered office of the corporation outside British Columbia with a receptionist or a person who appears to manage or control the corporation's business, or
with a director, officer, liquidator, trustee in bankruptcy or receiver manager of the corporation.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 161/2022, s. 76.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If there is difficulty finding a defendant
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a notice of claim cannot be served under Rule 2, the claimant may apply to the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)) who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: permit another method of service to be used, and
set the time limit for filing a reply.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If there is difficulty finding a defendant for service of a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim cannot be served under Rule 1.1 (10) to (17), the claimant may apply to the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)) who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: permit another method of service to be used, and
set the time limit for filing a reply.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When another service method is permitted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If another method of service is permitted, a copy of the registrar's order must be served with the notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim unless the registrar

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: orders otherwise, or
orders notice to be given by advertisement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of using another service method
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A notice of claim or notice of civil resolution tribunal claim that is served as permitted by a registrar's order is validly served.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice by advertisement
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a registrar permits notice to be given by advertisement, the party who obtained the order must pay for the advertisement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of other documents or notices
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Any document, record or other thing may be served on a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by following

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: Rule 2, if the person is not a corporation referred to in subparagraph (ii), or
subrule (6.1), if the person is a corporation incorporated outside British Columbia but is not an extraprovincial company,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless the document is a summons to a payment hearing or to a default hearing,
by mailing it by ordinary mail to the person's address, unless the document, record or other thing is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a notice of claim,
a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim,
a third party notice,
a statement of finances, a record or other thing referred to in Rule 12 (9), (11.1) or (11.4) or Rule 13 (6), or
a summons to a payment hearing or to a default hearing (see Rules 1.1 (10) to (17), 2, 5 (4), 12 (7) and 13 (5)), or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by emailing it to the person's email address for service, unless the document is a notice of claim, a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, a third party notice or a summons to a payment hearing, to a default hearing or to a witness (see Rules 1.1 (10) to (17), 2, 5 (4), 9 (1), 12 (7) and 13 (5)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When service by mail is effected
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document, record or other thing that is served by ordinary mail is presumed to have been served 14 days after it was mailed unless there is evidence to the contrary.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Written proof of service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Service of a document, record or other thing may be proved by filing the following at the registry:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for personal service of a document, record or other thing except a summons to a payment hearing, a certificate of service (Form 4), with a copy of the document, record or other thing attached;
for service by registered mail, a certificate of service (Form 4) with attached to the certificate

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a copy of the document, record or other thing, and
one of the following:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a copy, produced by fax or otherwise, of the signature obtained by Canada Post at the time the document, record or other thing was delivered;
a print-out of the delivery confirmation made available on the Internet by Canada Post;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for service by ordinary mail, a certificate of service (Form 4), with a copy of the document, record or other thing attached;
for service by email, a certificate of service (Form 4) with the following attached to the certificate:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a printout of the first page of the email message that includes the sender's name, the recipient's email address, the date the email was sent and the time the email was sent;
if the printout of the first page of the email message does not list the name of the document, record or other thing as an attachment to the email, a copy of the document, record or other thing;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for personal service on a lawyer or articled student, a copy of the document, record or other thing signed by the lawyer or student or by a partner or employee of the firm;
for personal service of a summons to a payment hearing, an affidavit of service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Oral proof of service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Instead of requiring proof of service under subrule (14), a judge or registrar may allow a person to prove by sworn oral evidence that the person has personally served a document, record or other thing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Change of address
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party's address changes, the party must file a new address for service (Form 38) and promptly serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Types of addresses for service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party must, on an address for service (Form 38), give both of the following types of addresses:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an address for personal service that must be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the party's residence, place of business or solicitor's office, if the party is not incorporated and not a partnership, or
the party's registered office, place of business or solicitor's office, if the party is incorporated or a partnership;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an address for service by mail or email that must be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a mailing address, or
an email address.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When service by email is deemed to be completed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document transmitted for service by email under this rule is deemed to be served as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is transmitted before 4 p.m. on a business day, the document is deemed to be served on the day of transmission;

if the document, record or other thing is transmitted on a day that is not a business day, or after 4 p.m. on a business day, the document, record or other thing is deemed to be served on the next business day.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If document, record or other thing does not reach a person
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document, record or other thing was served by email in accordance with Rule 18 (12) (c), a person may show, on an application to set aside the consequences of default, on an application for an extension of time or on an application in support of a request for an adjournment, that the document, record or other thing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: did not come to the person's notice,
came to the person's notice later than when it was served or effectively served, or
was incomplete or illegible.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Address for service must be filed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person wishes to file a document, record or other thing and has not yet given an address for service (Form 38), the person must also file an address for service and serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Time limits — transition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 18 (7) and (7.1), as it read on October 2, 2022, continues to apply in relation to a notice of claim, a third party notice or a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim filed before October 3, 2022.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Consequences of refusing to comply at a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person at a hearing before a judge

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: refuses to be sworn, or to affirm or to answer a question,
refuses to produce a record or other evidence,
does not obey a direction of the judge, or
repeatedly fails to attend court when summoned or ordered to do so and does not provide adequate reasons for failing to attend,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the judge may issue a warrant (Form 15) requiring the person to be imprisoned for a specified period of not more than 3 days.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the claimant or applicant refuses to comply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person who does anything referred to in subrule (1) is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claimant or applicant,
an officer, director or employee who is an authorized representative of the claimant or applicant, or
a partner or a manager of a partnership that is the claimant or applicant,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the judge may dismiss the claim or application.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the defendant or third party refuses to comply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person who does anything referred to in subrule (1) is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant or a third party,
an officer, director or employee who is an authorized representative of the defendant or a third party, or
a partner or a manager of a partnership that is the defendant or third party,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the judge may continue with the proceeding as if no reply had been filed.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Release from imprisonment for contempt
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person imprisoned under subrule (1) or Rule 13 (8) may apply to a judge who may order the person to be released on the conditions set by the judge.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a person cannot afford the fees
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Anyone who cannot afford the fees payable for registry services under Schedule A may apply to the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)), to be exempted from paying the fees.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Successful party to receive filing and service fees
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An unsuccessful party must pay to the successful party the following expenses, unless a judge or registrar orders otherwise:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any fees the party paid for filing any documents;
reasonable amounts the party paid for serving any documents, records or other things;
any other reasonable charges or expenses that the judge or registrar considers directly relate to the conduct of the proceeding.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Determination of expenses
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may determine the amount of the expenses that are payable under subrule (2) or refer the matter to the registrar.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar's determination
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge refers the matter to the registrar, the registrar must determine the amount of expenses as soon as practicable.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: A judge may order a penalty
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may order a party to pay the other party up to 10% of the amount claimed or the value of the claim or counterclaim if the party made a claim, counterclaim or reply and proceeded through trial with no reasonable basis for success.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Compensation for unnecessary expenses
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may order a party or witness whose conduct causes another party or witness to incur expenses to pay all or part of those expenses.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Compensation for collection expenses
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To compensate a creditor for the cost of collecting payment due under a default order or payment order, a registrar may order the debtor to pay expenses, limited to those in Schedule A.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Forms are in Schedule B
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The forms in Schedule B must be used in accordance with these rules and the instructions on the forms.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar may refuse to accept improper forms
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A registrar may refuse to accept a document for filing if it is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not in the form required by these rules, or
not completed according to the instructions on that form.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Reply — transition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may use Form 2 as it read on October 2, 2022 to reply in either of the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the reply is made under Rule 3 (2) in response to a notice of claim that was filed before October 3, 2022;
the reply is made under Rule 1.1 (21) in response to a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim that was filed before October 3, 2022.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Third party reply — transition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The requirement to use Form 3.1 to reply under Rule 5 (7) does not apply if the third party claim to which the person is replying was filed before October 3, 2022.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Statement of finances — transition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite Rules 12 (9) and 13 (6), a person summoned is not required to file a statement of finances if the creditor filed the summons, or if the judge ordered the payment hearing or default hearing, before October 3, 2022.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application of Supreme Court Civil Rules
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 23-3 (1) to (3), (4) (a), (6) to (14) and (16) of the Supreme Court Civil Rules applies to a claim under these rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Qualifications
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of subrule (1) of this rule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reference to Form 119 in Rule 23-3 (6) of the Supreme Court Civil Rules, as that rule applies under subrule (1) of this rule, is deemed to be a reference to Form 28 of these rules, and

a reference to affidavits in Rule 23-3 (11) of the Supreme Court Civil Rules, as that rule applies under subrule (1) of this rule, is deemed to exclude reference to affidavits of service under these rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Original documents
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document that has been transmitted for filing electronically under subrule (1) may be treated by the registry for all purposes as an original document.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 192/2007, s. (b).]

bcl:schedule.bcl:lefttext: In addition to any other fees payable under this Schedule, a further fee of $7.00 must be paid for transmitting a document package to a registry through the electronic filing service of Court Services Online. For the purposes of this provision, a "document package" is any document or, if a group of documents is transmitted at one time in relation to the same court file, that group of documents.

Despite anything in this Schedule, if, after consultation with the Chief Judge, the Crown enters into an agreement with a person under which the person is authorized to access one or both of registry records and specified registry services and is exempted from payment of any or all of the fees provided under Items 6, 6.1, 6.2 and 7 for such access, the person may, on payment of any fee required under the agreement and on compliance with any other terms and conditions imposed by the agreement, access, during the term of the agreement, the registry records and registry services to which the agreement applies without payment of the fees from which the person is exempted under the agreement.
